—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Aged Care. Is the minister aware of any proposed changes to the 30 per cent rebate for private health insurance? What would the impact of such alternative measures be on other Australians, but particularly on those in regional Australia?

talker.name: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP
Dr WOOLDRIDGE
talker.role: Minister for Health and Aged Care

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for his question. After yesterday's great news on private health insurance, the Labor Party cannot wait to get in and attempt to destroy the 30 per cent rebate as, in the words of Graham Richardson, `they do not really like private health cover'. The effects of this proposed change to means test the rebate would be catastrophic. If we look between 1985 and 1996, the drop-out from private health insurance in the top 60 per cent of income earners was 18 per cent. The drop-out amongst low income earners was only three per cent. So high income earners are far more price sensitive when it comes to private health insurance. Any change of this nature would immediately lead to a drop in private health insurance which means that premiums would go up.

answer.para: The Labor Party for the last six months have been trying to weasel and sneak around this. They say, `Yes, we are going to keep the rebate'—wink, wink. Yet, yesterday, the shadow spokesperson on health, the member for Jagajaga, said, `We have not decided whether or not we are going to means test.' This puts an end to the deceptive behaviour of the last six months. We can really see what the Labor Party are on about when it comes to private health insurance.

The honourable member asked about the effect of this. The effect is patchy because the number of people with private health insurance is actually not uniform across the country. The latest figures we have of people with private health insurance by electorate are from January 2000. But if we project by the state increase in private health insurance over the last six months we get some interesting figures. In the seat of Paterson, over 45 per cent of the population who have private health insurance are going to be disadvantaged by this change. In the seat of Bass, nearly 47 per cent of the population have private health insurance. In the seat of Dickson, 44½ per cent have private health insurance. In the seat of Griffith, 51.6 per cent of the population have private health insurance. In the seat of Kingston, 53.4 per cent of the population have private health insurance, and in the seat of Chisholm it is 55.3 per cent, which is just a bit above Jagajaga with 53.4 per cent. But the really high numbers come from Western Australia. In the seat of Stirling, 56.7 per cent of the population have private health insurance. In the seat of Swan, 54.2 per cent of the population have private health insurance. So these are the people the Labor Party are attempting to disadvantage, to undo the 4½ years of good work.

We do not have a consistent message coming from the Labor Party. They are all over the place. Clearly the New South Wales right wing would like the Labor Party to take a sensible position on this. The opposition leader is clearly not able to do that. He allows his shadow minister to go around undermining a very important part of Medicare. When it comes to private health insurance it is very simple: Labor did not invent the solution, they did not support the solution, they did not want the solution, but they are never going to be allowed to dismantle this.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr HOWARD
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The response I would make to Mr Cherrie—and indeed to the four or five other people who will be referred to as question time rolls on—is that I actually wrote to him. I wrote to him in a letter dated 20 June. It was addressed `My fellow Australian'. Had it not been for a court action I would have been able to make it a lot more personal. I would have been able to say `Dear Bill', `Dear Charlie' or `Dear Tom' , but unfortunately I was not able to do that and I had to use that time-honoured and well-respected generic salutation `My fellow Australian'. In that letter I referred to one of the many elements—would you like me to read the whole letter? It is a very good letter. And then I got to something that I would have been able to specifically draw to Mr Cherrie's attention—no doubt Mr Cherrie would have read this:

quote.para: Pensions and allowances will rise by four per cent on 1 July and will be guaranteed to remain two per cent above the cost of living.

answer.para: I then went on to say:

quote.para: In addition to increases in pensions and allowances, benefits for older Australians include savings bonuses, capital gains tax concessions, refundable franking credits and the abolition of provisional tax.

answer.para: But not content with that general explanation to Mr Cherrie, I then provided him with a very attractive booklet. And this very attractive booklet is very good. It is worth a read.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. —The member for Paterson will resume his seat. The level of interjection is much too high and I will deal very sternly with those who continue to defy standing order 55. The member for Paterson has raised a point of order that was not a valid point of order. The chair has at no time prevented people from quoting from documents, and that is precisely what I understood the Prime Minister was about to do.

—My point of order did not raise an objection to the Prime Minister quoting from the document that everyone in Australia received. My point of order was about the Prime Minister waving it around in a manner that you specifically have prohibited on other occasions and often.

—The member for Paterson's point of order is not valid. I will deal with the Prime Minister as I deal with all other members. The member for Rankin! The member for Rankin is warned. That was an act of direct defiance of the chair.

—I am indeed grateful to the member for Paterson for confirming that the Labor Party accepts that everybody in Australia received this booklet. Therefore any suggestion that anybody could have been in any doubt as to their entitlement is totally destroyed by your own interjection. It is totally destroyed.

—No amount of vigorous interjection by the Leader of the Opposition at the dispatch box can alter that fact. That destroys every one of the other questions you have organised—all these people who are writing in. If everybody has this document, everybody knows directly from me what the real situation was. So let me read it. Under the heading `Financial breaks: the GST and aged pensioners'—and I have already talked about the increase in the pension—it goes on to say:

quote.para: Pensioners will also benefit—

answer.para: and this includes Mr Cherrie and it includes Mr Holmes—

quote.para: from a 2½ per cent increase in the income test and assets test free areas, allowing you to increase the amount of income or assets you can have before your pension is reduced.

answer.para: It goes on to say:

quote.para: Pensioners will further benefit from keeping 60 cents of every dollar of income above the free area. Under the old system it is only 50 cents.

talk.start.para: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Speaker. The point of order goes to relevance. The Prime Minister is quoting from a document distributed halfway through this year, and we were asking questions about undertakings he gave before the election. Before the election he said everybody would get the $1,000. What he is putting out now—

—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat, and I will rule. As the Leader of the Opposition is well aware, the Prime Minister is entirely within the standing orders and is answering the question which he was asked.
—I will go on reading from the document under the heading `The aged person's savings bonus':

quote.para: Subject to an income test, Australians aged 60 years or over with personal income from savings, superannuation or investment will be eligible for a one-off aged persons savings bonus of a dollar for each dollar of that income. This is up to a maximum of $1,000 for a single person and $1,000 for each couple.

answer.para: The Leader of the Opposition will also be aware of an enormous amount of material that was circulated to Australian households before the election in 1998.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Would the Treasurer advise the House of progress in restoring Australia's fiscal position? Would the Treasurer comment on alternative approaches?

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr COSTELLO
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for Cook for his question. The honourable member would know that, in the last five years when Labor was in office, during a period of constant economic growth, the Labor Party accumulated for this country, for this Commonwealth government, $80 billion worth of debt. They ran deficits over five years and accumulated $80 billion of debt. We must pay tribute to the finance minister at the time, who I think has the record for the greatest two-year accumulative deficits in Australian financial history: $23 billion in two years. When this government was elected we said that we would do three things. We said that we would get the budget into surplus, we would halve the ratio of debt to the economy and we would do it without increasing taxes. As it turned out, we returned the budget to surplus one year ahead of target, after two years, we have done better than halve the debt to GDP ratio and, of Labor's $80 billion of cumulative deficits, we have now repaid $50 billion. We did that without increasing taxes.

answer.para: We saw the extraordinary claim yesterday, reported in the Australian Financial Review,which, as I remarked, must have been going into the comedy business after interviewing the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, who said that, after the Labor Party has rolled back GST, abolished bracket creep, rolled back fuel excises, paid small business to collect GST, increased spending on health, increased spending on education, increased spending on training, reviewed HECS and increased spending on the regions, it was actually going to run bigger surpluses than the government. Terry McCrann in the Herald Sun today reported it like this:

quote.para: `Labor pledges hefty tax hikes for middle Australia' was the headline you did not see in the Australian Financial Review yesterday, even though this was the most important message out of a cosy interview with Simon Crean.

answer.para: Where would you get the money to cut back the taxation base, increase spending on everything and run a bigger surplus? This is where we need to go to the Labor Party platform. I ask people to remember this very carefully. The Labor Party's platform is this—this is what they put in their platform, very deliberately: they will not increase the burden of taxation on lower and middle income Australians nor seek to raise revenue beyond a proportion of GDP over the past decade. They will not seek to raise revenue beyond a proportion of GDP over the past decade. Over the past decade, the tax to GDP ratio has been 22.5 per cent, but today it is 20.8 per cent. What that means, according to their platform, is a proposal to increase tax to GDP by 1.7 per cent or $12 billion. You would need every one of those 12 billion dollars to possibly be in the ballpark of those promises yesterday: $12 billion is an increase in income tax for every Australian, $12 billion would be something like a 36c a litre increase in excise on petrol, $12 billion would be the abolition of the 30 per cent health rebate and more. No wonder we saw the Labor Party spokeswoman on health yesterday equivocating on the private health rebate of 30 per cent. Ms Macklin said that she was not able to say if Labor would keep the rebate in its current form: `We will just keep watching how it goes,' she said.

`We will just keep watching how it goes'! Let me tell you how it goes: 30 per cent out to people who pay private health insurance—that is how it goes. That is how you will be watching it. Any means test on that private health insurance rebate, to save any money, to get to their $12 billion, would have to cut in on middle income earners. Thirty per cent for the average Australian family that loses their 30 per cent rebate means an increase of $700 per annum: $700 per annum every single year under Labor to take out private health insurance. Talk about a bill that will be coming to you courtesy of Beazley, Crean and Macklin! It will be $700 per annum on private health insurance, and that is before the Labor Party have got into their increase in income taxes.

The Labor Party did precisely this the last time they won an election, in 1993. I am going to read now the defence in this parliament given by Mr Kim Beazley as to why after winning the 1993 election they were entitled to hike up petrol excise, take away income tax cuts and put up wholesale sales tax, because that is what they did. When he was asked to justify how when they could go through an election without mentioning any of those things they were then entitled after the election to hike petrol excise, to put up income tax and to increase wholesale sales tax, he says this in Hansard on 28 September 1993:

quote.para: The opposition—

answer.para: and that was the coalition—

quote.para: was incapable of getting through the flack of its GST and presenting in the public mind the fact—

answer.para: and this is the fact—

motion.para: that if a government says it will maintain the current level of taxation as a percentage of GDP, yet its forward estimates on revenue suggest that the revenue will fall, then logically that government will raise revenue somewhere down the line.

answer.para: That was the quote. That was the justification for the increase in the petrol excise, the increase in the wholesale sales tax and the increase in income tax—that, if the forward estimates showed taxation revenue to GDP falling and the then government promised to keep it constant, that government was entitled to increase revenue down the track. And what do we find they do at the ALP conference?

talk.start.para: —The same thing.

—They make the same promise. When the Leader of the Opposition came in here blustering after the 1993 election he was saying, `You weren't clever enough to catch us.' That is what he said: `The opposition was incapable of getting through the flack of its GST.' Well, we are clever enough to catch you this time. You are making the same promise. We know from your statements to this House you think that promise justifies an increase in wholesale sales tax, an increase in income tax and an increase in petroleum excise. The Labor Party did it once; they are planning to do it again. The reason they will not come clean on any policy is if they did it is a $700 bill on private health insurance; it is an increase in income tax. The Labor Party are right back where they always were.

Yet the Labor Party voted against it. Don't you remember what you did? Don't you remember that you lined up on the other side and you voted against this? —I remind members, particularly those on my left in this instance, that if I need to take action I will, and that will mean they have voluntarily chosen to remove themselves from the House and deny their electors representation.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Would the Treasurer provide the House with an update on the implementation of the new tax system? What has been the reaction of the business and general community to the proposed roll back of the GST base?

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr COSTELLO
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for Riverina for her question. I can inform the House that registrations in respect of the new tax system have now substantially exceeded those which were forecast by the government. The government originally estimated that 2.1 million people would register for Australian business numbers. To date, there have been 2.6 million registrations. The government originally estimated that there would be 1.4 million businesses registered and to date there have been two million. That shows widespread acceptance of the new taxation system—notwithstanding all of the doom predictions of some in this House, whom I will not name—and that the government's registration machinery was well handled and on track. If I may interpose there, one of the indications of the acceptance of the new taxation system is that the goods and services tax now has bipartisan support in this chamber, with both parties committed, if they were elected at the next election, to keeping it. I welcome the Australian Labor Party's commitment to keeping the goods and services tax and recognition of the wisdom of the government's leadership role in putting it in place.

answer.para: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission was geared up from 1 July to handle 100,000 calls per day, but over the period from 1 July to 10 July 2000 it received only 15,000 calls—many fewer than it expected. It conducted a survey of price changes in 1,500 retail outlets and reported that 80 per cent of the products surveyed showed price ranges within the range estimated and that 97 per cent showed price changes of less than 10 per cent. About one-third of prices did not change as a result of the new tax system. I think members of the House would welcome that too, because you will recall that some people predicted everything would go up by 10 per cent or more. I will not go into who made those predictions. The reporting of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission was accurate, unlike some other price surveys that were put out at the time. Somebody in this House who put out a price survey—or, should I say, half a price survey—at the time said that it was not his responsibility to put out the full information. He had only a responsibility to put out those prices that had gone up. That was of course the member for Melbourne.

talk.start.para: —Seeing as he interjects, I could actually refer to his price survey and some of the comments that were made about it. I think the best comment about his price survey was made by a radio commentator who, on 20 July 2000, said:

quote.para: The story that needs to be talked about today is the prices survey of the Labor Party and opposition consumer affairs spokesman, Lindsay Tanner, regarded as one of the bright young things.

answer.para: He would want to look a bit brighter than he did yesterday. That commentator continued:

quote.para: Lindsay Tanner has released parts of the eight months survey only and of course in doing that he got caught. What the Labor Party has simply got to concede is that so far prices have not gone up all that much. I mean, it is always important in politics to be right with the facts. I mean, naturally, if you are going to lie to people you will get into trouble, and it is always going to be the same. And so the Liberals had a field day with Labor last night.

answer.para: Do you know which radio commentator said that? Mr Graham Richardson on 2GB on 20 July. Notwithstanding attempts by some in the Labor Party to put out false facts, as caught out by Richo, the price changes have gone very well. I think members would be aware that there is a proposal to actually roll back the GST. I think the whole of Australia was listening to the Hobart conference waiting for the words `roll back' to come out of the mouth of the Leader of the Opposition. We waited in vain. But small business and business generally have some views on roll-back. Rob Bastian from COSBOA said:

quote.para: Roll-back would increase—

talk.start.para: —He likes our proposal.
—He likes your proposal, does he? Good. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition cites Rob Bastian as supporting his proposal—Rob Bastian who, on 13 July, said:

quote.para: Roll-back would increase complexity, increase supervision and means increased fear.

answer.para: That is a wonderful endorsement! One of the Labor Party people said, `We are not here to represent small business.' Oh, we did not know how serious you were about that promise. Mr Bastian said:

quote.para: The uncertainty about roll-back has to be addressed. Mr Beazley is taking the usual political stand to keep his powder dry, but that position is not going to help. It is becoming an albatross around his neck.

answer.para: This is the person whom the Deputy Leader of the Opposition cites as his main supporter on roll-back. We would hate to see your opponents, old son, if he is your main supporter. The last thing that the small business council of Australia want, after all the effort and hard work they have put into it, is to have roll-back and more changes. They do not want any more changes. Phil Naylor from the Australian Retailers Association said:

quote.para: I do not think anyone would be really impressed with having to gear up for a new GST. We would like them to explain what they are proposing. We can't see any way you can fiddle with the GST that would make it less complex.

answer.para: Della was right. That is precisely what Della advised them. The reason you do not hear anything about roll-back is that they are in absolute confusion. They have no idea where they are going, let alone how they are going to fund it. They know that the moment they announce their roll-back, with all of its attendant costs, people are going to want to know what their new income tax rises are going to be. This would have to be the worst policy opposition that Australia has seen. They have no policy, no commitment and no credibility and they are going nowhere.

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP

talker.role: Minister for Financial Services and Regulation

answer.para: After receiving complaints from many consumers, as well as the member for Moreton and a number of other members, the ACCC investigated the matter. As it turns out, Queensland Motorways were misleading consumers. Perhaps I should add here who owns Queensland Motorways. Why has the Labor Party been involved in misleading consumers? Why is that the case? subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Petrol Prices

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, do you stand by your election guarantee that no petrol pump price will rise as a result of the GST? If so, how do you explain the comments of the AAA's Lauchlan McIntosh this morning that 1½c a litre of the recent increases is because of the GST, and the comments of Shell's Mr Vincent Cosgrove, who said that petrol prices during the month of July increased as a result of the GST, which is 1½c, and as a result of the increasing oil prices? That is 1½c due to your GST.

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr HOWARD
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The commitment made before the election was that the price of petrol need not rise as a result of the GST.
—The House will come to order!

—In monitoring movements in petrol prices, I prefer to rely on the assessments made by the ACCC. The ACCC monitored petrol prices in the week preceding the introduction of the new tax system and compared them with price rises after 1 July. I would have thought that, if you were endeavouring to assess the impact of the GST, it is the movements immediately after the introduction of the GST that would be relevant.

answer.para: The survey of approximately 4,000 service stations across Australia found that on average the major capital city price of unleaded petrol actually fell by 0.4c a litre following the introduction of the GST. Let me repeat that: the survey of approximately 4,000 service stations across Australia found that on average the major capital city price of unleaded petrol actually fell by 0.4c a litre. I heard what Mr McIntosh had to say, and I can respond only by referring to a survey carried out by the ACCC which disclosed that there was in fact a fall of 0.4c a litre in the days following the introduction of the goods and services tax. According to the Shell web site, the refinery price of petrol has increased subsequently by more than 6c a litre since 30 June.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has referred to the Australian Automobile Association press release by Mr McIntosh. The ACCC appears not to have taken into account exchange rate effects. The Australian dollar has depreciated by more than two per cent since the end of June. There have also been lags in the flowthrough of oil price changes to Australian petrol prices and also the retail discounting cycle. I do not accept the claims made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. I study remarks made by Mr Lauchlan McIntosh and the AAA. I do not give them any greater credence than that. When it comes to surveying price movements in Australia I prefer to rely on the ACCC, and the latest information from the ACCC is that in the days following the introduction of the GST the price of petrol actually fell.

—and the relationship between GST and tax and the total tax collection. I will listen to the Treasurer's answer but I did not deem his answer to be out of order from what I had heard.

I will just make the point that, in March 1983 when the Labor Party came to office, petrol excise—wait for it—was 6.1c a litre, but when the Labor Party left office in 1996 petrol excise was 33c a litre. It went from 6c to 33c. This is the only government that has not increased petrol excise other than by indexation, and the indexation that is applied is the indexation which was legislated for 17 years ago by a Labor Party. So when the Labor Party comes in, petrol excise is at 6c; it legislates to increase it; it legislates indexation; and it goes out with petrol at 33c. The Labor Party today is going to try to run an MPI on petrol because, as the member for Hunter said, `We can always make it an election issue but we know that thereafter nothing will ever be done about it.'

subdebateinfo.title: Refugees: East Timorese in West Timor

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Would the minister update the House on recent developments regarding the refugee problem on the West Timor border? What steps is the Australian government taking to assist with a resolution of this problem?

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr DOWNER
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for Wentworth for his question and the interest he shows in the situation in East and West Timor, which I know many members are interested in. The government is understandably deeply concerned over recent militia attacks, including the killing of two peacekeepers on the East and West Timor border. Indonesia has the ultimate responsibility for ending the incursions into East Timor, and our government continues to urge the Indonesian government and TNI in particular to redouble their efforts and take all necessary steps to end militia activity in West Timor. We have made numerous representations to the government of Indonesia along these lines; indeed on 29 July I spoke to Indonesian Foreign Minister Alwi Shihab about precisely that.

answer.para: Resolution of the border security situation partly depends on resolving the refugee camps issue. We welcome the Indonesian government's proposal to close the refugee camps as a step in the right direction. Importantly, Indonesia has acknowledged that dealing effectively with the camps is fundamental to solving the problem of militia activity. We are giving a high priority to discussions with the Indonesian government, the UN and other members of the international community to explore the difficult practical steps needed to implement Indonesia's proposal. The government of Indonesia must provide effective security to ensure that there is no militia intimidation and that there is unimpeded access to camps for the United Nations High Commission for Refugees and a credible registration process. It is crucial that the refugees are able to exercise their choice on resettlement in Indonesia or repatriation to East Timor, free of any intimidation.

Australia is of course ready to offer constructive assistance to both Indonesia and to East Timor. We have already provided $7½ million to assist people in camps and facilitate their return to East Timor. We are prepared to do considerably more.

Mr ANDERSON
talker.role: Deputy Prime Minister

But the first point I want to make is to reinforce what the Treasurer and the Prime Minister have said, which is that our overall take on excise is down by about $2.2 billion. answer.para: Let me make one point here, firstly. It is an important one and it is this: no-one rejoices in the fact that right across the globe at the moment, as a result of high crude oil prices, petrol prices are very high. It is worth noting that we have seen a 47 per cent increase in the price of crude in recent months; but, despite that, in fact the price of petrol in Australia is the fourth lowest in the world. The particular point that the member raised that needs addressing is that he clearly sought to imply that country motorists were somehow worse off as a result of our policy approach. The fact of the matter is that the Australia-wide differential has narrowed. It is considerably narrower now than it was 12 months ago, as a result of the government's policies. Indeed, the most superficial glance across a whole range of centres in rural and regional Australia will show that the differential has continued to narrow. It has narrowed more since the introduction of the new taxation arrangements.

The fact of the matter is that, unlike those opposite, we are reducing the collection of excise. You never, for example, made the excise or, in this case, the GST on business petrol rebatable. talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —We will give the benefit of the doubt and say that the question involved a thorough misunderstanding—no doubt written by somebody else, but showing a thorough misunderstanding. talk.start.para: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Hunter proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

quote.para: The failure of the government to deliver on its election promise that the GST will not lead to an increase in petrol prices.

interjection.para: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —During question time today, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer were at their sleight of hand best. I deliberately excluded the Deputy Prime Minister from that statement because his contribution, when asked a question during question time, was not even worth noting. But the Treasurer once again, as he has done on numerous occasions in this place, passed up the opportunity to answer a very simple question. That very simple question went something like this: is the government raising today more revenue from petrol excise and taxes that it was two months ago? Every consumer in this country knows, as we know on this side, the answer to that question is yes. But what did the Treasurer choose to do? He attempted to aggregate revenues from diesel with petrol in a sleight of hand attempt to mislead the Australian people.

speech.para: Let me turn to the Prime Minister, who I suggest should be the main target in respect of this matter of public importance today. Let us go back to 12 April this year when I asked the Prime Minister a question with regard to petrol. I asked the Prime Minister on that occasion how he expected to meet his pre-election promise that the GST would not force petrol prices to rise and, in particular, I asked him how he planned to meet that promise in Parramatta. While delivering my question on that occasion, I made the point that, on that day at the Mobil service station on the corner of Victoria Road and Macarthur Avenue in North Parramatta, unleaded petrol was 84.9c a litre. I ask members on both sides of the House what they suspect might be the price of petrol today at that same service station in North Parramatta. Would they expect it to be still 84.9c a litre? That is what the Prime Minister would have us believe, according to his answer during question time today. The answer of course is no. Is it 86.9c a litre? No. Is it 90.9c a litre? The answer again is no. The price of unleaded fuel at that same service station—the one I referred to on 12 April this year when petrol was at 84.9c a litre—is today at 94.9c a litre. Yet the Prime Minister wants us to believe that the GST has had no impact on the price of fuel. It is now 10c higher, yet he refuses to answer these simple questions.

In that same question time in response to a later question on the same issue the Prime Minister said, `Why don't you come back and ask me after 1 July?' Here we are, Prime Minister, well after 1 July and we are putting the simple question to you: how is it you have not been able to meet your election promise? I can only suspect that his answer on that occasion was founded on two things. The first was hope—hope that between that date and 1 July the price of world crude oil would fall enough to make the obvious impact of the GST on petrol prices less obvious. The second was that he had in mind a secret plan—a secret plan that was going to surprise us all, a secret plan that was going to put the critics of his pre-election promise on the canvass.

Before I go to the PM's secret weapon, let me remind the House why he found it necessary to foreshadow a new initiative with respect to the keeping of his pre-election promise. Having promised that the price of petrol would not rise as a result of the GST, the Prime Minister committed to a reduction of 7c a litre in the price of petrol. He had worked out at that time that for prices up to 77c per litre the arithmetic was such that the 7c reduction would have ensured that petrol need not rise as a result of the introduction of the GST. As I indicated, that theory was okay for prices up to 77c per litre. But for prices beyond 77c per litre the arithmetic changed significantly, and the Prime Minister was left with no choice but to concede that a 7c reduction in the excise on fuel would not be sufficient to meet his pre-election promise.

I remember the lead-up to 30 June very well. We were all waiting with great expectation. The great question was: would he lift the ante to 7.5c per litre reduction in petrol excise, would he go to 8c, would he go to 8.5c, would he go to 9c? Expectations were very high. But surprise, surprise! The Treasurer came—no, I will not say that the Treasurer came into this place. He did not do that at all.

talk.start.para: —He went to Paris.

—I think he was in Paris at the time. Instead, at 4 o'clock in the afternoon of Thursday, 22 June, the Minister for Finance and Administration sneaked out into one of the courtyards in the gaze of the media and announced that the reduction, having conceded that a 7c reduction was not sufficient, would not be 9c per litre at all, that it would not be 8.5c, that it would not be 8c, and that it would not even be 7c. The minister for finance announced that the reduction in fuel excise, to our surprise, would be 6.7c per litre, having conceded that a 7c reduction was not sufficient. You have to ask the question: how could this possibly be? The minister for finance explained on that day that the government had suddenly discovered some embedded wholesale sales tax savings that the major oil companies should be passing on to consumers. They were savings that the ACCC had not identified in its GST pricing guidelines and savings that the major oil companies were quick to denounce, and they produced independent modelling soon after that date that proved inconclusively that there were not significant embedded wholesale sales tax savings to be passed on.

speech.para: So the question then is: where does this leave the petrol consumer? It leaves the petrol consumer the victim of the Prime Minister's broken promise—a promise he now attempts to run away from, a promise he now attempts to amend to `need not rise' instead of `will not rise'. The commitment was clear that the GST would not cause petrol prices to rise, and it is a commitment that he has repeated on a number of occasions in this place. Where does that leave the consumer? It leaves the consumer in an electorate like mine paying at best, in the better towns where competition is most fierce, around 97c per litre. But where does it leave other consumers in further flung areas around the country? Where does it leave consumers in Queenstown in the electorate of Lyons, who are paying $1.04 per litre? Where does it leave consumers in Launceston in the electorate of Bass, who are paying $1.03 per litre today? How does it affect consumers in Middlemount in the electorate of Capricornia, who are paying $1.09 per litre today? Yes, I can see the adviser noting them down so he can check them later. That is helpful. Where does it leave consumers in Nguiu in the electorate of the Northern Territory, who are paying $1.20 per litre today?

talk.start.para: —One dollar and sixty cents.

—You changed the town and I forgot to change the price. I thank you for your support—$1.60 per litre. None of those consumers either in my electorate or in the marginal electorates on the other side have any doubt at all why they are paying so much for their fuel. They know that one of the major factors at play here is the impact of the GST on petrol.

speech.para: What is the GST on petrol? It is a tax on a tax. What has the government done? It has introduced a GST which layers over an existing fuel excise. What does the GST do? The GST causes inflation to rise. What happens when inflation rises? Petrol excise, which is linked to the CPI, also rises. What happens when petrol excise rises? The GST, which lies on top of the petrol excise, also rises. So the GST is a tax on a tax, spiralling upwards. We all know that as the CPI continues to spike and then increase less rapidly petrol excise will continue to rise, as will the impact of the GST. So the Treasurer's answer during question time today should have been a simple yes. The facts are obvious. But instead he sought to attempt to aggregate revenue taken from petrol with revenue taken from diesel excise.

That was not the only announcement that came from the minister for finance on 22 June. The other was some clarification on the government's so-called fuel grants scheme. This is the other initiative taken in a desperate attempt to fulfil the pre-election commitment that petrol prices would not rise. This is the $500 million scheme that will go to people in certain areas—and there are a number of anomalies concerned with that, which have been highlighted here before—where consumers will get a 1c rebate or in some cases a 2c rebate. But we know, and the evidence is already there, that that $500 million of taxpayers' money will do no more than line the pockets of the major oil companies.

There is a history of deceit from beginning to end. The government continue to try to run from the questions during question time when they should be conceding that there is a revenue windfall with respect to petrol prices as a result of the introduction of the GST. They should be admitting as much to the Australian consumer, who knows only too well the impact of the GST on petrol. During question time today the Treasurer raised another matter, that is, Labor's commitment to petrol prices. Labor has got a number of commitments to petrol prices. Again, I am happy to concede that history will show that political parties of all persuasions have, at a number of elections over decades now, made commitments to improve not only the fluctuations in the price of petrol but also the differential that exists between city and country prices. Labor still is committed to doing so, in great contrast to the government which is taking this windfall.

talk.start.para: —How?

—The minister at the table, the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, asked me a very simple question: how? Firstly, by taking the exact opposite approach to that taken by those who sit opposite. The approach by those who sit opposite is to take $500 million of taxpayers' money and hand it to the major oil companies. The $500 million fuel grants scheme largely goes straight to the major oil companies because they largely run, whether directly or by commission agency, the service stations in this country. Secondly, the government repeatedly endeavour not to curtail the power of the major oil companies—which is the biggest problem in the petrol market—and wind back their ability to manipulate prices and take excessive profits wherever and whenever they can, but to give them more power by deregulating the petrol industry at the retail level. We take a different approach. Firstly, we start from the foundation that the GST is inherently unfair as it applies to petrol. Secondly, we think that power needs to be curtailed. Thirdly, we think there needs to be greater competition not only at the retail level of the petrol industry but also at the wholesale level where the major oil companies have absolute control. I have got a few views on how that can be done. Firstly, introduce more competition at the wholesale level by giving service station operators the opportunity to shop around for their fuel instead of being tied to an exclusive arrangement with one particular major oil company.

speech.para: The minister at the table might explain to me why the price of fuel in Muswellbrook in my electorate is consistently lower than it is in Singleton, closer to Newcastle, and Scone, above it, further from Newcastle. It is simply because there is greater competition in Muswellbrook as a result of the entry of Woolworths to the retail market. I suggest to him the best thing he could do is support a proposition to introduce more competition at the wholesale level as well.

talk.start.para: —No, that is not what you want. You want to take prices surveillance out in readiness for the arrival of the GST and then concoct figures, as the PM did today, to suggest that it is ridiculous—ask any consumer—to suggest that petrol prices have fallen as a result of the GST. No-one will have that. (Time expired)

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
Mr HOCKEY
talker.role: Minister for Financial Services and Regulation

talk.start.para: —I am going to go to the parliamentary shop steward and ask that the member for Hunter be given a raise. I think he deserves a raise because he had the good fortune to come into this House after the introduction of the GST, introduce a matter of public importance on the GST and get up in this House and explain the Labor Party's position. What we just heard from the member for Hunter is a major policy statement on the application of tax to fuel. If I heard correctly—and we will check Hansard—the member for Hunter pledged that the Labor Party will abolish the $500 million fuel grants scheme to rural and remote Australia. I asked the member for Hunter what the problem was with the current scheme. He said, `The first thing that we would do is get rid of the $500 million fuel grants scheme to rural and regional Australia.' That was the first thing he said. The member for Hunter pledged it. The Leader of the Opposition was sitting at the table and said nothing. Finally, at last, we have got a snapshot of roll-back. That snapshot of roll-back is that rural and regional Australia will be $500 million worse off because the 1c and 2c a litre subsidy going out to them that started on 1 July ends if the Labor Party ever comes into government. Thank you, I say to the member for Hunter, because you have just given us a snapshot of what roll-back means.

speech.para: We know the member for Hunter is genuine in circumstances such as this because, as the Treasurer pointed out in question time, when the member for Hunter was interviewed on Hunter Valley 2NM with Chris Lewis on 24 July, the member for Hunter said:

quote.para: My pledge to my party—

speech.para: `My party'; that is, the Labor Party—

quote.para: is this: that petrol prices have been an issue for decades. At every election they become an election issue. But after the election the problem remains no matter who wins.

speech.para: There is one clear, unequivocal point about petrol prices, and it is this: the most significant impact on petrol prices and the volatility of petrol prices is the volatility of world crude oil. That has the biggest impact on world petrol prices. If you look at the petrol price out of Singapore, which is our main source, you will see that it was $22 a barrel in February last year. Today it is more than $60 a barrel. So, from February 1999 to today, the price of a barrel of unleaded petrol out of Singapore has risen from $22 a barrel to $60 a barrel—and the Labor Party pretends that it has had absolutely no impact whatsoever at the pump!

If you take what the member for Hunter just said—and he said it in front of his colleagues and he said it in front of the Leader of the Opposition—the Labor Party are in fact going to roll back the $500 million subsidy, the 1c and 2c a litre subsidy that is going to people in rural and remote Australia. He pledged that here in this House, in Hansard, and that is a taste of roll-back.

talk.start.para: —You already said that.

—I will say it again. And I will say it again because if the member for Hunter and other members of the Labor Party actually make a slip and come into this House and give us some idea of what roll-back means, I say, `Great,' because it is time for those over there to tell the truth. It is time for the Labor Party to start telling the truth. It would have been easy to dismiss this MPI as yet another groundhog day. Here we go again. Another MPI from the Labor Party on the GST. Here we go again. There is one big difference between all of the other MPIs I have done and today: on 1 July the GST started; on 1 July the GST came in, with a raft of other tax reforms that delivered income tax cuts, that delivered higher pensions and that delivered better family benefit payments. On 1 July we abolished the excise, put in place a GST. On 1 July every business in Australia registered for the GST and got 10 per cent cheaper petrol. Every business, every small business in Australia, got 10 per cent cheaper petrol on 1 July.
—What about the consumers?

—I will tell you about consumers—businesses supply consumers. In the ideal world that the member for Paterson would create the government would be the only supplier of goods and services to consumers—the old socialist rhetoric coming to the fore again, bubbling to the surface. It is a bit like oil in water: it always comes to the surface. In this case, the fact is if business gets it cheaper, consumers get it cheaper. That is how it is delivered. That is how a capitalist economy runs. Business gets it cheaper, price exploitation laws, ACCC powers: consumers get it cheaper—a market economy. Isn't that great? Don't we think that is terrific? That is what we want. That is the sort of capitalist democracy that most Australians want, and that is certainly what those of us on this side of the House find ourselves increasingly trying to protect—protect it from you, the Labor Party. We are trying to protect it from the Labor Party. That is what we are trying to do.

speech.para: If you are really talking about petrol prices I want to know what roll-back means when it comes to the application of the GST to petrol. I want to know if it means the abolition of the diesel fuel subsidy—24c a litre—which started on 1 July. We heard from the member for Hunter today that it means the abolition of the 1c and 2c a litre subsidy for rural and regional Australia. What does it mean for businesses, all of those businesses out there that get 10 per cent cheaper petrol as a result of the introduction of the GST? What does it mean for those businesses? I will tell you what it means for those businesses: roll-back means that those businesses are going to have to pay more for petrol. Roll-back for those businesses means that they are going to pass on higher costs to consumers. That is what roll-back means.

talk.start.para: —GST hasn't given them cheaper petrol.
(Mr Nehl)—The member for Paterson will have his turn in a little while.

—Thanks to the member for Hunter we have got a snapshot of what roll-back means for petrol prices under the Labor Party. They have already pledged in this House today to increase petrol prices in rural and remote Australia by 1c and 2c a litre. They said it: abolishing $500 million, which the member for Hunter claims goes directly to the fuel companies.
—That's the second time you have run that argument.
—Well, it is a damn good argument, and I will keep running it. And I will tell you why I will keep running it: because it was a slip.
—It wasn't a slip.

—It wasn't a slip? Here I was thinking that for a brief second that Labor had unveiled the curtains on roll-back. I even gave the member for Hunter the benefit of the doubt, and he says across the chamber, `There's no slip. We're just going to abolish it'—$500 million for rural and remote Australia. The member for Hunter has pledged today in the House in front of his leader that they are going to abolish it.
—The member for Hunter has had his turn.

—We are going to come back to this. I feel it coming back over the next few days. I can feel it coming back. Wait a second: question time on Wednesday, question time Thursday. And we have got another two weeks in two weeks time. There is all of next year. We have got a few question times there, a few question times to remind the member for Hunter of his pledge in this House before the Australian people, before his colleagues, to abolish the $500 million subsidy. That is courageous politics!

speech.para: And here I was thinking the member for Hunter had a bright career. Here I was thinking that surely Labor caucus would have to accept the advice of the right wing and start putting some right wingers other than just the Victorians into one of their economic portfolios. Here I am thinking, `Gee whiz, the New South Wales Right goes down to the national conference—did you hear this?—and says, "Hang on a sec, all the economic portfolios are occupied by Victorians. They are occupied by Simon Crean, they are occupied by Stephen Conroy, they are occupied by Kelvin Thomson, they are occupied by Lindsay Tanner. We want to put up one of the right wing from New South Wales."' They put up someone from the right wing of New South Wales; they put up the member for Hunter. Now the member for Hunter is expressing economic policy for the Labor Party. I say, `Good on you, Joel. We're there with you buddy. Fight on. We're there with you buddy.'

talk.start.para: —Thirteen times, and five minutes to go.
—The minister will address his remarks through the chair, and the member for Hunter will be silent.

—It has taken a hell of a lot of MPIs to find out what roll-back is. It has taken a hell of a lot of debate in this House to get a bit of a picture. It has taken a hell of a lot of time, a lot of rhetoric, a lot of newspaper columns and a lot of hours on talkback radio, but now we are starting to get a picture of roll-back. Now we are starting to get a feel for what it really means.
—The door's just opening.

—It has opened a little. The door has been left a little ajar. It was an innocent question. I was sitting right here. How many questions have I asked generally across the chamber? I sit in this chair and I ask a little question of Simon Crean and I ask a little question of Lindsay Tanner. I ask a whole lot of little questions and there is a little bit of niggling and we never get an answer. Today I pull the one-armed bandit and bingo: I won. It all came down. Now I do not have the arms to carry all the coins—$500 million worth of subsidy in coins.

speech.para: I would like to thank the member for Hunter for his very generous contribution to this MPI. I think it was genuine; I think the member for Hunter is a pretty genuine guy. It is a legitimate question that the Attorney-General asks: `What has the member for Hunter to say about the surpluses?' We want to know. Do you agree with the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that the surpluses are going to get bigger? We know what he means by `roll-back'.

talk.start.para: —Does the member for Hunter agree that the Labor Party can deliver higher surpluses?
(Mr Nehl)—The member for Hunter is pushing it uphill.

—He has already pushed and pushed, Mr Deputy Speaker. Keep pushing, Mr Fitzgibbon! We are waiting for Michael Costello to stand outside with a baseball bat. It already has a notch on it for Della Bosca for telling the truth and now it is going to have a notch on it for Fitzgibbon for telling the truth. We have another notch on the baseball bat. It is a real club—it is a big weighty club—and it says, `Anyone who tells the truth, I am going to hit you.' It is a nasty baseball bat because there is a tradition in the Labor Party that if you tell the truth you get caught. In the Labor Party if you tell the truth you get sacked. You get rewarded for telling a fib.

speech.para: We had the member for Melbourne running around after 1 July saying, `Here is my price survey. It is Armageddon, isn't it? It is terrible out there. There is blood everywhere.' He did not get sacked after it was discovered that he was not telling the whole truth. No, he is still sitting there on the front bench. But Della Bosca comes along and tells the truth and he gets sacked as president of the Labor Party. We are going to watch with interest what happens to the member for Hunter because today he has told the truth. The Labor Party are going to abolish the $500 million subsidy for rural and regional Australia in the form of a 1c and 2c per litre subsidy on every petrol station, on every litre sold in rural and regional Australia, and I say to the member for Hunter: thank you, old mate.

talk.start.para: —Having listened to the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation all I can say is that, while he may be a good after-dinner speaker, when he comes into a debate here he either has not read the matter before us or refuses to address it. The copy of the MPI that I have is titled `The failure of the government to deliver on its election promise that the GST will not lead to an increase in petrol prices'. You can interpret that in two ways: it can be a debate about petrol prices or it can be a debate about election promises. Having sat through question time today, I would like to take the tack about election promises.

speech.para: We know that we have a Prime Minister who cannot utter the words, `I am sorry.' So on behalf of the people of this parliament who want to apologise to the people of Australia, I want to say that I am sorry. I want to say that I am sorry to all those pensioners out there who thought they were going to get $1,000 because they had seen the Prime Minister on television say, `You are all going to get $1,000.' I want to apologise to all those independent retirees who thought they were going to get $2,000. Particularly, I would like to apologise to all of those people in Australia who thought that the price of petrol was not going to rise because they had been assured by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer of this nation that the GST would not increase the price of petrol—not once and not twice, but many times in this House.

As a matter of fact, the Treasurer is on record last November as trying to explain that you take a certain amount of excise away, you put a certain amount of GST on and the price stays the same. We all know that—the shadow Treasurer mentioned that in question time today. But we all know that in the stealth of night, while the Treasurer indeed was in Paris, 6.7c went off and 8.2c went on. We all know that since 1 July, as petrol prices have increased and therefore the GST component of petrol has increased, the price of petrol is the highest that we have seen it in living memory, particularly in most regional areas. I was particularly interested today to hear that the city-country regional difference is lower. It is lower, there is no doubt about that. I saw an article in one of the weekend Sydney papers that in, I think, Double Bay petrol on Saturday went to 107c per litre. I dare say it was pre-Olympic testing of the market or something like that. But the whole point is that today we saw a disgraceful exhibition from a Prime Minister and a Treasurer of a government that is in denial. They are in denial of promises that they made—try as much as they like to get out of it. We heard the Prime Minister say, `It does not matter whether the term was "would not" or "should not"'. He said, `It did not.' We all know that it did.

The fact is that, since 1 July, petrol pricing has escalated. The Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, who is at the table, said in the debate today, `I will tell you why petrol pricing got dearer. Crude oil got dearer.' Maybe the minister would like to be reminded of what he said in Hansard. I have a news release from the Australian Automobile Association, which says:

quote.para: In releasing the latest monthly petrol price monitoring for July, the Australian Automobile Association has expressed disappointment that the Treasurer and the ACCC have not investigated petrol price rises. The latest monitoring shows that despite a fall in world oil prices of $US1 per barrel between June and July, the average July retail price in capital cities rose by about 4 cents per litre.

speech.para: We have just heard from the minister, the Hon. Joe Hockey, that the price of petrol is related to the escalation in the price of crude oil. The Australian Automobile Association says that the price of crude oil fell by a dollar. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer promised that petrol prices would not, should not and could not rise, but they have risen— hallelujah, brothers, hallelujah!—and the people of Australia want to know why. The word of the Prime Minister can no longer be accepted in this country because it is simply a fact—and everyone knows—that petrol prices have escalated. It has denied the principle that the minister indicated.

Today in question time the Prime Minister denied that he had promised $1,000 to every pensioner. Anyone who watched the clip on television last night saw him clearly and unequivocally promise $1,000 to every pensioner—they saw him utter those words. He says, `Go back to page 58. Oh, I am sorry, it's page 11.' Why did he say that on television when he was going to have it printed in a book. He knows that the book would be read by a fraction of the people of Australia whereas what was said on television would be seen by the majority of the people of Australia. That is the power of television.

Again, we come back to the integrity of the government and the honesty of the Prime Minister, and we find that not only do we have core and non-core promises; we have written and spoken promises, which is confusing to the people of Australia. What promises do you believe? I suppose you have core written promises and non-core written promises, and you have core spoken promises. It is just too confusing. Why can't they say what they mean? How can the price of petrol rise when the Prime Minister said in question time today that petrol prices did not go up? Maybe the Prime Minister should go on a tour of Australia and find out what people in regional Australia are paying.

I can tell you that in Dungog which is only 70 kilometres away from Newcastle, Australia's sixth biggest city, the price of petrol is 103.9c a litre. What is the GST component on high petrol prices for the government? The Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Deputy Prime Minister were trying to deny today that this government is not getting a bigger tax take from petrol. We asked that question specifically about petrol. We did not want to know about businesspeople; we did not want to know about people who use diesel; we wanted to know about the ordinary punters like you and me out there who drive petrol cars and use petrol and we cannot claim it off our tax because we do not run a business. That applies to the majority of people who live in rural and regional Australia. They are hurting because of the policies of this government, and this government is denying that that is so. The Prime Minister actually denied that petrol has risen today. Let him go to rural and regional Australia and just find out. Let him go and ask the pensioners that he promised $1,000 to, who are probably driving a leaded petrol car, what they are paying for petrol. He promised them $1,000 that he did not deliver and he promised that petrol would not get dearer—and it did.

Be it about the integrity of government or be it about petrol prices, this government fails on both parameters. Today the government has revealed its arrogance by ignoring what the people of Australia are trying to tell it. They are trying to tell this government that the word of the Prime Minister, be it written or spoken, be it a core or non-core promise, can no longer be relied on. Polls are taken about whether you can trust a politician, but it comes back to the leader of the government, back to the Prime Minister, and he has dodged around telling the truth in the House today. I feel ashamed at being labelled a politician who sits in the same House as he does.

talk.start.para: —The last comment of the member for Paterson was that he felt ashamed. It is true that members of the Labor Party should feel ashamed. Let us go through some of the history of fuel pricing in Australia. The cost of fuel in Australia is high because of the Labor government. When the Hawke government was elected in March 1983, fuel excise was just 6.155c per litre. It was twice that by March 1986 under the Labor government; three times that—18c—by the middle of 1986; four times higher by 1990 under Labor governments—it was 24c a litre then; it hit a fivefold increase in 1994 under Labor governments; and, at the time of the 1996 election, fuel excise on unleaded and diesel fuel was over 34c a litre. It is no wonder the member for Paterson felt ashamed, being a member of the Labor Party in this current parliament with that history of his predecessors.

speech.para: Of course, the opposition should feel ashamed for another reason. Today, in this very opportunistic debate under the MPI brought up by the opposition, they have ignored the fact that the basic cause of the high price of oil and fuel not just in Australia but in the world is high world prices. They have increased by about 47 per cent to August this year. We did not hear a word from the shadow minister, the member for Hunter, or from his cospeaker, the member for Paterson, about that basic intrinsic fact. If they want to be seen to have credibility in their concern about the cost of fuel in Australia, they first of all have to explain why the Labor Party's policies forced the price of fuel so high for the 13 years they were in government. They also have to explain why they failed in this important debate to explain that the basic cause of increased fuel prices in Australia and in the world is the increase in the world price by about 47 per cent to August this year.

Why didn't they mention that? They did not mention it because they are attempting to do what they were doing before 30 June, when they were predicting the roof would fall in due to the GST in Australia and when they were opposing the GST. Before 30 June, they were distorting the facts, misrepresenting information, concealing material information and trying to cause concern. On 1 July, the sky did not fall in and they are now going to keep the GST. They are humbugs. They said before 30 June that they would not keep the GST and after 1 July they have said they will keep it but they are going to roll it back.

Today we have heard the member for Hunter give an undertaking as shadow minister that the next Labor government in Australia will roll back and take from country people—and I am one of the members of this parliament who represent country people—the 1c to 2c in additional historic grant given by the Howard-Anderson government to rural people, consumers, businesses and others. Let me say this: they will not get away with it. The announcement made today by the shadow minister is that Labor intend to rip off from country people, country motorists and country consumers, the Howard-Anderson grant to rural petrol consumers in Australia of 1c to 2c, amounting to about $500 million per year. But it will not be taken from those people. People are entitled to that allowance and the Howard-Anderson government will ensure that they retain it. We will fight right through to the election to oppose the Labor Party's plan to take it from country people. They will not get away with it.

Furthermore, on the opposition's roll-back position on GST, we in the coalition in city and country will be working closely together to stop the Labor Party—if they become the government—taking from businesses in Australia the input credits that we have been able to give them as part of the major tax reform in this country. In my towns—in Wangaratta, Benalla, Euroa, Wodonga, Bright, Myrtleford, Yarrawonga and Corryong—and in other places, a small business like a plumber with his ute will get about $600 or $700 a year taken off his fuel costs because all the GST in the price of fuel at the bowser in Australia will be rebated to small businesses. It is an input cost. The battlelines are drawn. We are very happy to hear the member for Hunter make these disclosures. We are also very happy to be able to tell the Australian community that in the months leading up to the election we will do all we can to stop Labor getting into power, to stop them taking the input tax credits and the fuel rebate away from small business and to stop them taking away the rebate that John Howard and John Anderson have been able to give—that is, the $500 million to country users of fuel, whether they be in business or not.

Let me just say how sad it was to hear the second speaker for the Labor Party, the member for Paterson, say that he did not want to know about the fuel cost for business and small business. He actually said that today. I say that he should hang his head in shame. We have 900,000 small businesses in Australia. They are the engine room of Australia. They are all over Australia: they are in the country, in the regions and in metropolitan areas. We care about them. But this senior Labor member was backing up his shadow minister on today's MPI by saying, `We don't want to know about the cost of fuel to small businesses.' That is what he said. It is an extraordinary statement. He said, `All we want to know is what it costs for the consumer.' That is a typical example of their narrow perspective and the way in which they try to wriggle and misrepresent policies to people.

talk.start.para: —You just made that up!

—No, I did not. It is the truth. I think the member for Hunter should be relatively quiet this afternoon because he has threatened to take away the $500 million rebate to country people, which he will not get away with. We will not let him get away with it. But now his colleague the member for Paterson says, `We don't want to know about the cost of fuel to business.' The government want people in businesses in Australia to know that they now get an input tax rebate back on the cost of their fuel. Under the major tax reform, the small plumber, the farmer or whoever they are in country or city in Australia will now get the cost of the GST refunded as a business input as a result of the Howard-Anderson tax reforms.

speech.para: The member for Hunter is the spokesman for small business for the opposition on occasions, and he has an interesting perspective on small business. I often listen to him with interest. I know a bit about his background. I would have thought that he would be rejoicing and saying, `The alternative government takes the view that of all the things in tax reform we will want to respect the fact that for the first time ever businesses in Australia, small, middle and large, will get taken off their fuel the business input, that is the GST component.' But it is not so. They do not want to know about that either.

The MPI today is a shabby attempt to rescue something. I listened carefully yesterday at question time and again today when the Treasurer asked the opposition to indicate their position regarding roll-back, surplus and GST. There was silence. Obviously, what has happened is that the Labor Party are desperate for strategy. They say, `We have to cobble something together. Fuel is an emotional issue. Fuel prices have gone up. We know it is mainly due to world price movements and other things, but we will get poor old Joel, the member for Hunter, and we will use him. We will whack him in the House and try to concoct this motion and this emotional argument.'

The opposition have been caught out because they cannot deny the fact that fuel prices have increased—not only in Australia but also worldwide—by 47 percent up to August this year. Now do you deny that? Why didn't you say that? You have lost your credibility. If you want to come into this House and talk about reforming fuel, the Hydra-headed monster, you have to be fair dinkum. You have to put all the facts on the table, not the piecemeal stuff, not the opportunistic stuff, as you have tried to do today. It is to your eternal shame that you have done that and missed the opportunity to have a decent debate on the other issues regarding competition that we can work together on. The opposition in the Senate have got together to stop the government's further reforms with respect to fuel in Australia. There is a story to be told there which they will have to account for at the next election. The MPI is a sham. It is a cheap, opportunistic trick to try and plug into the emotion caused by high fuel prices around the world and it should be rejected out of hand. (Time expired)
