debateinfo.title: RETIREMENT ASSISTANCE FOR FARMERS SCHEME EXTENSION BILL 2000

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 29 June, on motion by Mr Slipper:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme Extension Bill 2000 that the House is debating tonight amends the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 to enable farmers to continue to access the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme from 14 September 2000 to 30 June 2001—an extension period of nine months. This extension measure was announced by the government in the 2000-01 budget. It was prompted primarily by the poor rate of take-up of the scheme when matched against the government's own expectation of possible participants who might access this provision.

speech.para: This is not the first time and not the only portfolio area where this government has announced a policy initiative accompanied by a very optimistic and some would say deceptive expectation of that initiative's potential to address a particular situation—in this case the intergenerational transfer of farms. Members might recall the fanfare that accompanied the announcement of the original scheme by the then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, John Anderson, in October 1997. The minister in his press release of 21 October 1997 said:

quote.para: A preliminary review of ABARE Farm Surveys data suggests as many as 10,000 farms could potentially meet the eligibility criteria for this measure.

speech.para: The government in this House, and of course in the public arena, made great play of this initiative and bandied about the 10,000 figure as if that number of farm enterprises had already entered the scheme. It was touted as a major structural adjustment initiative of significant scale and would address in a very real sense the issue of intergenerational transfer of farms. It is now a matter for the public record that around only 1,400 farms have availed themselves of the scheme. Of the $77 million which was originally allocated for this purpose, only around $10 million has been committed to the task. This is an issue that I intend to take up a little bit later in the debate.

The issue of intergenerational transfer of farms is an important one to the rural sector. Anyone who has grown up on a farm and who has parents who have farmed for many years understands the very strong attachments of people to their land. In some families the same property has been farmed for several generations, and it is always an extremely difficult personal decision for a farmer to relinquish not only ownership but control, even to another member of the family. There would not be too many farmers' children who do not understand the point I am making here.

I grew up in the western district of Victoria on a small dairy farm. I know it was a difficult decision for my father to end his farming days and to sell the property. My father through illness had ceased to farm and crop. In his latter years he performed a caretaker type of role on the small farm that he loved so dearly. He was the youngest, along with his twin brother, in a family of 11 children. He had to leave the farm to find consistent employment, and he spent many years working in Melbourne. He finally realised his dream after many years and after the war, returning to where he was born and raised to purchase the property and to do what he dearly loved to do—and that was to farm.

He farmed for most of his life, rearing four children in difficult economic circumstances. He invested his emotional and physical energy in building the farm up and earning a living. When the time came to relinquish ownership and leave the farm, he was initially unable to do it. It took several years of gentle persuasion—and sometimes not too subtle persuasion—to bring him to a decision to finally leave. He died suddenly before he was able to sell the property and to re-establish himself and his wife in retirement. It then took the family another few years to persuade my mother to finally leave the property. There is no doubt that throughout the sector this sort of sentiment has prevailed, and it is not a sentiment easily understood by those who have not experienced it. Many people understandably react adversely to what they perceive to be special treatment of farmers in this regard, without perhaps having the sensitivity that is borne out of first-hand experience of the attitude of farmers to their land. The whole issue of succession planning and the intergenerational transfer of land is a sensitive one and quite difficult to manage on farm. That is why special provisions have been structured to assist the process of intergenerational transfer of farms within the rural sector.

The problems confronting the sector and successfully effecting this intergenerational transfer can be readily appreciated when one examines the 1996 census data on the age distribution of Australian farmers. In the 1996 census, it is recorded that there were 25,343 farmers over the age of 65. There were an additional 17,341 farmers between the age of 60 and 64. In the younger cohort, between the age of 55 and 59, there were 22,543 farmers recorded. When you combine those three categories, there are some 65,127 farmers, according to that census data, in the over-55 and 65-and-over cohort—that is out of a total registered farming population of around 199,000. That comprises about 34 per cent of total farm numbers.

So we can see from those particular figures that I have quoted that we have a problem in the rural sector that I think both sides of politics have adequately acknowledged—that is, we have an ageing farming population. That presents all sorts of problems to the sector. We are in a process of significant global challenge and cultural change. As we know—and it is a natural state of affairs—sometimes the older we get the more conservative our attitudes become to adapting to change and to taking on the challenges that are often posed to us. I think that is fair enough because people do bask in the efforts that they have made in the past on their farms. They have secured their livelihoods in many instances and see no reason to adapt to a change in circumstance. But I think it is very important to appreciate that over time we are going to have to address this issue of the ageing of our farm population. It has implications not only for the provision of a whole variety of services in rural and regional Australia and the survival of many rural communities and towns but also for the productivity of the sector over time.

The scheme that the government introduced was an attempt to address the issue of the intergenerational transfer of farms. But in the literature surrounding that particular announcement and in subsequent views that have been expressed by people such as the New South Wales farmers organisation there appears to be some confusion as to the objectives of this particular scheme and how it should operate. Nevertheless, I do concede that it has been an honest attempt by the government to structure a set of arrangements to ease that intergenerational transfer of funds. I think the government has made some significant errors in the announcements that it made and, at the end of the day, it has not had the take-up that it anticipated. This scheme has not lived up to the expectations set out in the minister's original speech to the parliament in introducing this particular scheme.

If we look at the provisions of the scheme, we see that there are several provisions that some in our community might think are very generous. As I said before, the original piece of legislation was designed to encourage farmers to consider the issue of passing on their farms and enjoying the lifestyle to which they have been accustomed by residing on those farms and in their local communities on retirement. Some features of the legislation are that the government did set a time limit of 15 September 2000 for farmers to take advantage of the scheme. The government did raise expectations on the number of farmers that we could expect to take advantage of the scheme, and that has not been realised. As far as the provisions go, the transferor must be a natural person, not a company, but may be a farmer alone or the farmer in conjunction with a spouse, and the value of the farming interest must not exceed $500,000. To qualify, the farmer must have been in farming for 15 years or, if he or she has been in farming for at least 20 years, have acquired the relevant interest in the farm prior to 15 September 1997. Another provision is that the farmer's income is means tested. An average of the farmer's income over the three years preceding the completion of the transfer is compared with the pension entitlement currently at $10,059.40 a year for a single pensioner and $16,780.80 for a couple.

Those particular provisions do indicate to the community that it is not just a case of all farmers being able to access this particular scheme. There are some restrictive provisions and the government initiated a review of the scheme last year, and in that review some very constructive suggestions were made by interested parties about how these provisions ought to apply. The reality is that these particular provisions mean that many farmers are not entitled to access the scheme, and I think that goes some way to dispelling those concerns in parts of the community that the scheme might have been overly generous as these provisions do not apply to similar businesses, say, in rural communities and rural towns.
But I want to return to the obvious failure of the government to meet the 10,000 target it originally set for the scheme. In view of the obvious policy failure in this area, I move:

motion.para: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for failing to meet its target under the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme of allowing up to 10,000 older farmers to retire with dignity with control of their farm assets passing to the next generation.".

speech.para: In moving this amendment, I want to draw to the attention of the House the fact that, when the minister originally announced this scheme, the government trumpeted very loudly out in the community that 10,000 farmers would be eligible to take up this scheme. They created the expectation in rural Australia that farmers would be able to access the provisions of this scheme when the government probably knew very well that the restrictive provisions would prevent many farmers from accessing the scheme.

It is this issue of expectations that I want to address here tonight in this particular debate, because even as we debate other matters in this place, and even as we debate them here in the House today, this whole issue of the government raising expectations and then tending to renege on the promises that it makes comes up. I refer here to the GST compensation issue when pensioners and self-funded retirees were promised by the Prime Minister that there would be an element of compensation for them in the GST compensation arrangements which was far in excess of what the Prime Minister knew and promised these people would receive. Once again we had the coalition creating an expectation among older Australians that they would receive $1,000—and, in the case of self-funded retirees, $2,000—as compensation for the impact of the GST on their savings. It was a solemn promise that the Prime Minister made. But, as we know, this Prime Minister is one who has made a habit of making promises. When he broke the big promises to the Australian community, including farmers, older farmers and veterans, he came up with the cute terminology, `Oh, no. It wasn't really a promise; it was a non-core promise.'

Mr Deputy Speaker, if you went out to farming communities and you said to a farmer, `Well, we've had this discussion. Here is what I intend to do, and I will make you a non-core promise,' they would get up from the table and walk away. But the city lawyer the Prime Minister is, and his stockbroker and lawyer mates on the front bench of the Liberal Party, have no perception of the sort of honesty that is required by farmers when you deal with them. It is this essential dishonesty that regrettably has found its way into the attitudes of the National Party senior ministers in this coalition who, on too many occasions, have gone along for the ride with their city based Liberal counterparts to the detriment of the rural community. I say to the Prime Minister: go out to rural and regional Australia and make a few more non-core promises. You will be laughed out of the regional towns, you will be laughed out of the small rural communities and you will be laughed out of the areas where farmers gather to discuss matters of family and politics.

But it is not only the issue that we are debating here today where the government raised expectations; it raised them on the GST compensation package and it also raised them on the issue of fuel. We have had in this place National Party ministers who have supported the Prime Minister's original proposition, when the GST package was announced, that petrol prices would not rise under the GST arrangements. Once again, the Prime Minister made them a non-core promise because he then changed his terminology to `petrol prices need not rise'. Now we know that, directly as a result of the introduction of the GST, petrol prices have risen and the Prime Minister's promise to farmers on petrol is in tatters. But it is not only in the area of petrol that the great deceiver—and I call the Prime Minister the great deceiver—has pulled the wool over the eyes of the rural sector of this country but also in the area of diesel fuel. The government went out to rural communities and said to the farmers of this nation, `We are going to introduce a set of arrangements that are going to lead directly to a lowering of fuel costs in rural and regional Australia that will flow on to goods and services in the form of lower prices in rural and regional Australia.' We now know that that is another promise that the Prime Minister has not been able to keep. We also now know that the government, through its taxation arrangements on diesel, has its hand in the pockets of farmers to the tune of $25 to $60 million. We are not quite sure what the exact figure is, but farmers out there know it, the New South Wales Farmers knows it and the National Farmers Federation know it. After we exposed the government on this particular issue, the farmer organisations got into the public ring to call the government to account because they realised that this city centred Liberal coalition government had dudded Australia's farming community again on diesel.

So on these three issues—the policy issue we are debating here tonight, the retirement assistance plan for farmers; the issue of the GST compensation package; and the issue of fuel—we have seen the government raise expectations about what it was going to deliver, and of course it has failed to deliver. This is what the New South Wales Farmers Federation had to say in their submission dated 31 March 1999 to the retirement assistance for farmers scheme review:

quote.para: The scheme is not effectively targeting that sector of agriculture which would make best use of its provisions. The Association has had experience with many farm families who were led to understand, by the Government announcements, that this program would enable them to hand on the family farm, yet were unable to access assistance. Many of these families are trying to support three generations on the one farm, but were still not eligible.

speech.para: The New South Wales farmers have gone to the very point that I have been making in this debate thus far: this is a government that creates expectations—expectations that its GST arrangements will lead to lower prices in rural areas, when they know it will not; this is a government that has raised expectations of massive benefits flowing to rural and regional Australia by its fuel arrangements, yet farmers know that they are paying more for their petrol now than they did before the GST. We can even take out the increases that have occurred because of the increase in world prices for the product, and they are still paying more for their petrol. Now they find that this coalition government has its hand in their pockets for another $25 million on the diesel fuel arrangements. There is some confusion, I think, in the stated objectives of this farmers retirement assistance scheme. The minister's original question press release said:

quote.para: Mr Anderson said the initiative was deliberately targeted at low income farmers with relatively low assets because this was the group experiencing the most serious financial hardship.

"The families that will benefit from this measure are those that up until now have not been able to afford to transfer ownership of the farm, even with the States exempting them from stamp duty on these transfers."

speech.para: In this press release the minister is saying that this measure is being squarely aimed at low income farm families; yet a different interpretation of the scheme is given by the New South Wales Farmers Federation submission that I just previously referred to. This is what the New South Wales Farmers Federation have had to say about the objectives of the scheme:

quote.para: As outlined by the Government, the objective of this policy measure is not to assist unviable farmers off the land but to enable them to pass a viable farm on to the next generation. This objective appears to have been lost somewhat in the implementation and it is essential that this review redirect the program towards its original intention.

The Terms of Reference for this review state that the aim of the scheme is to facilitate the agricultural adjustment process through the inter-generational transfer of viable farms. It does not mention the targeting of low asset and low income farms yet this is the category that is targeted by the scheme.

speech.para: Here we have the government stating a set of objectives for the scheme back when it was introduced and conducting a review where the terms of reference are interpreted in quite a different way. It is important that the government clarify exactly what its objectives are with this scheme. It needs to do that for farm organisations and for farmers themselves.

This is a very important issue to the sector. The government has made an attempt in this legislation to address the issue. But we do not believe, given the expectations that were raised by the government about this initiative when it was announced, that the government has succeeded in meeting its own objectives for the scheme. Indeed, we are highly critical of the fact that this is a government that goes into the rural sector raising expectations about what it might deliver and then reneges on that—be it the Prime Minister's `non-core promises' on a whole range of issues or be it this scheme.

In the time remaining to me in this debate I want to address an issue that was raised in the House today in question time by the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry when he in quite an extraordinary way accused the Labor Party of not having a platform on agriculture. If the minister wants to come in here and make political hay while he thinks the sun is shining, that is his prerogative; but I am a bit surprised that the minister is acting like his Prime Minister in this statement of deceit to this House today, because the national conference of the Labor Party did pass a platform. Just to clarify for the minister, the platform is not a detailed set of policies, and we will not be announcing that detailed set of policies until we are in the zone where the Prime Minister is going to put the nation to the polls. We will over time, between now and that election, indicate to the rural sector where we believe the priorities in agriculture should be. Our great task is going to be to maintain the productivity of the sector in the face of the great environmental and global challenges that it will face. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—Order! Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

—I am absolutely incredulous that members of the opposition would come into this chamber and bag the government for the way they have addressed the fuel situation in rural and regional Australia. This is the same opposition that voted against abolishing the 24c a litre diesel fuel excise and that voted against every measure the government took to relieve the load of not only farmers but also businesses and taxpayers in rural and regional Australia. So I am surprised that someone could come into this chamber from the other side and talk about how the government has made promises on fuel prices and not delivered them.

speech.para: I take the example that if indeed the opposition had supported the government in their attempts to lower the diesel fuel excise we would not have had the situation where we have this slightly complex formula for how people have to apply for the Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme. If the Labor Party had voted with the government on this, we would have been able to deliver a whole lot more than we actually did to rural and regional Australia in the area of fuel. The speaker from the Labor Party talks about this and other attempts that the government have made to ease the load on rural families. Yet the reason why the AAA package was brought in—the reason why it was so critical that it be brought in—was the absolute and utter mess the rural economy had been left in after 13 years of Labor.

The Labor Party has absolutely no interest in rural and regional Australia. To take one example, the interest rates that were absolutely crippling people living on farms, who were paying anything up to 28 per cent interest, had far more of an impact on the viability and ability of such people to make a living than anything this government has done. This government came in in 1996 and it has made great strides in improving the viability of farms in Australia. As I said before, it is absolutely amazing that the opposition would come in here and even speak in such terms on this bill.

I strongly support the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme Extension Bill 2000 and to some degree I agree with the previous speaker. It certainly is not easy for farmers who have been on the land for some length of time, often all their lives and possibly involving a previous generation, to make a decision to leave that farm. This retirement assistance for farmers in financial difficulties is only one of the key components of the successful Agriculture Advancing Australia scheme. Other assistance was offered—for example, the Farm Family Restart Scheme. Another part of the Agriculture Advancing Australia scheme which was so welcome and useful in my part of the world was West 2000. It was a pleasure just recently to be able to announce that the federal government had continued to fund West 2000 with the West 2000 Plus scheme.

These are a few of the measures this government has taken to improve the viability of farms and the livelihood and lifestyle of people on the land. For example, it was announced that the West 2000 funding was to be allocated by western people for western people. West 2000 Plus, which is a continuation of that scheme, has also been extremely warmly welcomed by people in western New South Wales. It has enabled farmers to build up their properties and make them a viable size. There are also various other measures like woody weed control. One of the most important aspects of the West 2000 and West 2000 Plus schemes is the education component. I think it is very easy to say that the uptake of this retirement assistance package was not what was expected. Perhaps part of the reason for that is so many other things were introduced at the same time that enabled farmers who perhaps might have taken up the package to improve their viability by continuing education, building up their farms and taking up the myriad of other opportunities this government has made available to them.

This scheme was introduced by this government in 1997 as part of a sustained approach to provide economic impetus and support for the rural sector. Since then the package has delivered unprecedented backing to all elements of the agricultural industry through enhanced competitiveness, viability and therefore profitability. But at the same time, the Agriculture Advancing Australia project included provision to assist those farmers struggling to cope financially in the form of this Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme. Since being introduced in September 1997 the retirement assistance initiative has served as a reassuring safety net for some 1,400 retiring Australian farmers and their families. The retirement assistance scheme allows older farmers to transfer their farm to the next generation without jeopardising their access to age pension payments or, where applicable, service pensions. As mentioned by the previous speaker, this bill seeks to extend this invaluable scheme by nine months to 30 June next year and, in doing so, allows more farmers to utilise the benefits and pass their farm operation on to younger generations without penalty.

This retirement assistance most benefits farmers who are confronted with financial difficulty because their farm business has to provide a livelihood for two families when, in reality, the operation has the capacity to support only one. It does so by removing a significant barrier to the transfer of the family farm from one generation to the next, that being the delay for retiring farmers in receiving pension assistance. They will be able to pass on their farm to their children as a going concern, confident that the new owners will be able to make a more viable living, and they will receive pension support immediately.

From a broader community perspective, maintaining the farm in family hands will foster greater economic confidence and allow long-time farm couples to retire in dignity and comfort. This extension of the scheme will not change the eligibility criteria. Farmers will still need to qualify by meeting the same conditions that have applied for the past three years—some of which were mentioned by the previous speaker—those being that the net value of the farm must be no more than $500,000, that retiring farmers must have owned the property for at least 15 years or been actively involved in farming for 20 years, that retiring farmers must have had an average income less than the age pension rate in the previous three years, and that the next generation to which the property is being handed must have had an active involvement in the farm for the three years prior to the transfer.

Quite clearly conditions need to be placed on a scheme such as this because it is targeted at those farmers who are the least viable. I am sure that if, for example, the criterion for the net value of the farm were increased to $1.5 million, we would hear squeals of protest from the opposition saying that it was too generous. The noise made by the opposition, on the one hand, is about farmers not having taken up this program while, on the other hand, they accept that there still need to be conditions so that farmers in the target group are the ones who are actually taking it up. By extending this worthwhile program, the government will have contributed to a stronger farming community and allowed older farmers—including numerous armed forces veterans—to retire having placed the family farm in safe hands. Coupled with federal initiatives such as the recently announced $18 million Farm Innovation program to financially back new ideas in the farm sector, this government is constantly making new ground in boosting the fortunes of primary producers. Such an approach is particularly critical in my electorate of Parkes in western New South Wales, where we face many challenges. We have a limited ability to diversify, so any assistance to provide innovation on the farm is most welcome.

There are many other significant impediments placed in the way of young farmers in my part of the world and in other areas of New South Wales, not the least the savage restrictions the New South Wales Labor government have placed on clearing. There are many areas both in my electorate and in other parts of New South Wales where young farmers have bought country and have cleared small parcels of that country with the intention of clearing more in a sensible and sustainable way to pay off the loan and provide an income and a lifestyle for their family. Many of these farmers have had the wool pulled from under their feet when the Labor government in New South Wales changed the rules, severely restricting farmers' ability to plant crop and therefore severely restricting their ability to produce an income. In fact, many young farmers from my part of the world have actually up and left the farm because of the impositions the state Labor government have placed on them.

As a predominantly sheep grazing and wool-producing area, the impact on farmers of a slump in the world wool market and commodity prices has been dramatic and long term in some areas. Emerging alternative farming methods and products, ably supported through the funding efforts of this government, augur well for the next generation of farmers to take control of the farm operation. Freed from the burden of trying to provide income for two families, the farm's chances of remaining a viable income source are increased. But in the state's far west, where the options for farming other than sheep grazing are more limited, the drought has greatly aggravated the economic situation. Here the prospects for two-family farm operations are most dire, and it is in these communities that support mechanisms such as retirement assistance for farmers are most needed and appreciated. It is essential that governments continue to offer incentive and support to the farming communities that are the cultural heart of areas such as western New South Wales. The more farmers' offspring that can be kept on the land, the more a confident sense of economic security and stability can be maintained in our small rural communities. The curse of the asset-rich but cash-poor farmer is well recognised. By extending this assistance scheme, we continue to right the wrongs of fiscal circumstance for older farmers on less profitable holdings.

Small communities, in my area and in others, rely heavily on the economic wellbeing of the surrounding farming operations and, as a result, the balance between remaining a service town or becoming a virtual ghost town is a delicate one. By striving to provide both the incentive to excel on the one hand and a safety net for embattled older farmers on the other, this government is meeting its commitment to the people in the non-metropolitan heartland of this country. In areas hardest hit by the reversal in the fortunes of traditional produce, this scheme is a commonsense approach to delivering the best outcomes for individual farmers and the wider communities in which they live. I look forward to seeing the uptake of this scheme in the next nine months. As the previous speaker noted, it is an emotional decision for farmers who have worked and lived on the same farm or in the same area for all of their lives and the lives of their ancestors. It is not surprising that the uptake of such a scheme has perhaps not been what was predicted, but giving the farmers another nine months to consider their positions and make the decision that will put them and their families in the best possible position in the future will be welcome. I commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme Extension Bill 2000. I note with interest the comments by the member for Parkes, for whom I have the greatest admiration as he is a dedicated member for his area. He mentioned that the uptake was not as expected, and I hope in this contribution to suggest exactly why. I suggest the criteria that apply to this legislation exclude those who by any judgment should qualify for access to this scheme.

speech.para: In March 1999, the Commonwealth Department of Family and Community Services announced a review of the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme. That review was to address the extent to which the scheme is meeting its objectives, having regard to targeting and take-up rates, the factors which promote or inhibit access to the scheme, and the justification for and cost and equity of any suggested changes to the eligibility criteria. Having dealt with many RAFS cases over the preceding two years, I took a keen interest in that review. But, after I had waited over a year and after my office had contacted the review on a number of occasions, it became quite obvious the review's findings were unlikely to be made public. In April this year, I placed a series of questions directed at the Minister for Family and Community Services on the Notice Paper. The questions were aimed at trying to ascertain what the outcome of the review, commenced over a year previously, had been. I asked:

quote.para: Is the three year window for gifting of family farm assets under the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme scheduled to end on 15 September 2000; if so, why is the Government yet to respond publicly to the review provided to the Minister in mid 1999 by the Minister's Department.

speech.para: The minister's response, received on 9 May 2000, budget day, was:

quote.para: Yes, the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme which provides a three year `window of opportunity' for low income, pension age farmers and their partners to gift their farms to the younger generation, retire from farming and qualify for the age pension is due to finish on 15 September 2000. The departmental review of the scheme is currently being considered by the Government in the 2000-2001 Budget context.

speech.para: I asked:

quote.para: Among other things, was the purpose of the departmental review referred to in part (1) to (a) assess the extent to which the scheme was meeting its objectives, (b) assess the factors which promote or inhibit access to it and (c) examine the justification for, and the cost and equity of, any changes to the eligibility criteria for the scheme and its extension past September 2000.

speech.para: The response was yes to all parts. I asked:

quote.para: Will the Department's report be made public, if not, why not.

speech.para: The minister's response was:

quote.para: The Government is currently considering the future of the scheme in the context of the 2000-2001 Budget. No decision has been made as to whether the departmental report will be made public.

speech.para: I further asked:

quote.para: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to problems people have had accessing the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme because of the rigidity of the eligibility criteria, including the problems (a) resulting from the requirement that assets be personally gifted, rather than gifted from a company or trust and (b) caused by the treatment of equitable interests such as life estates.

speech.para: The response was yes to both aspects. Thankfully the minister was at least aware of the types of complex problems I had dealt with in my office. I asked further:

quote.para: Will the Government extend the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme; if so, what changes will be made to the eligibility criteria ...

speech.para: The response was:

quote.para: (5)(a) The Government is considering the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme and the need for any changes to the scheme in the context of the 2000-2001 Budget.

(b)The Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme has been effective as a welfare measure to assist needy farmers. As at 28 March 2000 more than 1550 farmers and their partners have been successful in being granted an age or service pension or an increase in their rate of income support payment under the scheme. This is in line with initial estimates that the scheme would assist some 2100 farmers and their partners during the full life of the scheme.

speech.para: That night the Treasurer announced that the cut-off for the RAF Scheme would be extended nine months, from 15 September until 30 June 2001.
In introducing the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme Extension Bill 2000 to this place on 29 June, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration claimed:

quote.para: Since its introduction in September 1997, the scheme has assisted more than 1,400 retiring farmers and their partners.

speech.para: On the one hand, we had the minister saying in May that some 1,550 out of a planned 2,100 farmers had been able to access the scheme. On the other hand, a month or so later we were told that the scheme had assisted more than 1,400 retiring farmers. I hope the minister can let this place know exactly how many people have been able to access the scheme and also, importantly, how many have missed out. In fact, this parliament has a right to know just what the departmental review of the scheme found.

When the bill was introduced, the parliamentary secretary made no mention of the review whatsoever, no mention of the extent to which the scheme was meeting its objectives, no mention of any factors which have promoted or inhibited access to the scheme and no explanation of why the decision had been taken to extend the scheme without altering its eligibility criteria. I also note there is nothing in the explanatory memorandum that sheds any light on these issues either. As is so often in its dealings in this House, the government—and no doubt the previous government was the same when I was not in this place—expects this place to neatly pass the bill and to rubber-stamp it without providing its members, the non-government ones at least, with any real detail about how the policy has performed over the last three years.

I call on the minister to explain to this place whether any decision has yet been made about whether his department's review of the scheme will be made public. I further ask the minister to allow that review to be tabled in this place and, if that cannot be done, to explain why not. I can understand why the government may not have wished to make the review public prior to the budget, but now that that extension has been announced surely there should not be a problem. This is of course unless there is something in the report which suggests that more than just a mere extension of the policy was required or that it has not been as effective as some would have us believe. Members need to know what the outcome of the review was so they can make an informed decision about whether the proposed response is the best way to go.

The Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme intended to allow older farmers to transfer ownership of the farm to a younger generation, to retire and to gain access to the age pension. It did this by allowing farmers, subject to certain strict criteria, to gift their family farm and avoid the social security assets test which otherwise deems gifted assets as assessable for five years after the gift is made. The scheme was developed from a recommendation from the special rural task force, established by the government shortly after it came to power in 1996. That task force examined the impact of the social security assets test on rural customers. The scheme originally offered a three-year moratorium or `window of opportunity', which was to have run from September 1997 to September this year. During those three years, farmers otherwise excluded by the social security gifting rules might gain access to the pension.

When the government announced the scheme, it estimated its cost during that three-year period would be $77.6 million. Yet as of March 2000, according to management information provided by Centrelink, actual expenditure on the scheme amounted to just over $10 million. The estimated cost of the extension is $9 million. The obvious question is: what happened to the other $55 million or so that has not been used by the scheme? Perhaps the minister can provide this place with an explanation about that also. The funds budgeted were so underspent they seem to me to point to problems with the criteria. The stipulations may be too onerous, as was argued by me and others in this place and the other place when the original legislation was considered. To have $55 million or so not spent also suggests that there is room to move to further loosen the eligibility criteria for the scheme to allow more suitable retiring farmers to access the assistance.

The member for Corio outlined the criteria that must be met. I will not repeat those, except to say that under those criteria a younger generation must have been actively involved in the farm for the three years immediately before the transfer. The member for Parkes pointed to—and no doubt other speakers in this debate will—the absolute necessity to maintain the family farm unit in rural Australia and, if possible, to ease that transition from one generation to the next. I put it to the House in this debate that the criteria that have been applied are excluding people who by any definition should access the scheme. The criteria for assessing the scheme are onerous.

When the bill putting in place the RAF Scheme came before this place on 2 June 1998 I applauded the government on its initiative. I said it was the first time such a move had been introduced, I said it was sorely needed and I said it was welcomed in the community, but I also argued the government should look more deeply at how meaningful it would be and how many people would really be assisted by it with the thresholds being so strict. In particular, I supported the moves by the National Farmers Federation and the Democrats to increase the farm value threshold—not to $1½ million, as has been suggested—from $500,000 to $800,000. As with the totally inadequate property valuation included in the tax integrity measures bill, the government seems locked into the $500,000 farm valuation threshold. For what reason I am not quite sure. I also supported at the time the moves to increase the annual income cut-off from the maximum pension rate to $20,000 per annum.

Throughout the life of the policy I and my staff have dealt with a large number of inquiries from people who have faced problems accessing the scheme. These cases have demonstrated to me a number of problem areas within the legislation. This extension bill could have rectified these, but instead because we are keeping the legislation in its current form they will remain. The first of these problems is the requirement that retiring farmers personally gift what the legislation calls their `qualifying interest'. This requirement did not appear to take into account the many farming enterprises owned and operated through a company structure. In order to access the scheme, farmers operating their property through a company must first transfer ownership of the property from the company to themselves personally and then to their children. This caused problems on two fronts: first, the extra legal expenses incurred in the double transfer and, second, the state stamp duty impost on the transfer.

For a qualifying retiring farmer running their farm through a company structure, depending on the value of their property, stamp duty in the range of $20,000 to $30,000 was not out of the question. Obviously such an amount would be beyond the means of a retiring farmer with income in the range which would allow him access to the scheme. Thankfully, after numerous representations the solution was found to this problem, not at the federal level but at the state level. I do not know what happened in other states but in at least one case I dealt with the New South Wales state government saw the impracticality of the federal legislation. It waived the stamp duty in order to allow the transfer to go through and the applicant to access the pension. I do commend the New South Wales government for at least applying some commonsense to its stamp duty legislation. I wonder though just how widespread such exemptions are and whether there are people out there who have not been able to access the scheme because of the stamp duty burden. This is the sort of thing the department's review, if made public, could tell members.

The second problem area related to the treatment of farming ventures run through trusts. In particular, there was some confusion spelt out to me about whether a trustee of a trust that holds a farming property has a `qualifying interest' in that property under the terms of the scheme. While the legislation specified that only legal estates or interests were treated as `qualifying interests' under the scheme, Centrelink's policy document interpreting that section stated that `a farmer who is a trustee of a trust which owns the farms and farm assets has a qualifying interest in the farm'. Arguments were put by the solicitors of at least one applicant I represented that such a trustee held an equitable—not legal—interest, and therefore the department's interpretation conflicted with general legal principles. Thankfully, in that case a one-off solution was eventually reached for the applicant, but only because the trustee farmer's name did not appear on the title documents of the land held by the trust. Once again, that solution was reached only after many representations, both legal and political, made on his behalf. The question must be asked: how many people in similar circumstances missed out? Yet another matter which perhaps the department's report shed some light on.

Another problem area with the policy lies in the property valuations used by Centrelink. I recall dealing with the case of at least one Orange district farmer where the valuation used was far in excess of the going market rate for similar properties. Once again, after considerable representations a solution was reached in that case, but only after the valuers admitted they had erred in their valuations.

Another problem area with the scheme lies in the requirement that the entire farming enterprise be transferred. My office has had a long involvement with one case where this requirement appeared to have an unfair and perhaps unintended impact. The applicant had transferred his property to his son in 1995 but had not transferred the full property at Manildra. He had kept 50 acres surrounding the house in his own name. The reason why he had not transferred the full property was that at the time he could not afford the surveying and consequential expenses associated with having the house and surrounding two hectares removed from the land transfer. The 50 acres already apparently existed on a separate title. He has derived no income from that acreage which is farmed with the rest by his son, but since 1995 he has had his pension reduced under the social security asset test deeming provisions. And I reckon that is unfair.

When RAFS was announced, he applied for it and, by applying, he hoped he would not have to wait the full five years before getting his pension increased—nor, I suggest, should he have. The veteran constituent had taken his application for RAFS through the Department of Veterans' Affairs internal review process. It was rejected at every stage. His appeal was ultimately rejected by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal a month or so ago. That farmer's five years is now up and he can finally access the higher pension under the normal rules. But he wrote to me recently expressing his frustration at the two-year ordeal he went through—and I say `needlessly'. He wrote among other things:

quote.para: ... the point I am making is that everything one reads in the Veterans Affairs Newspaper, the indication one gets from the Department of Veterans Affairs, the Minister concerned the Hon. Bruce Scott and the Howard Government is that they are bending over backward to make life easier for war veterans ... what I consider is that I have got just about the opposite.

speech.para: What that case and many of the others I dealt with demonstrated to me was that many applicants found it difficult to get detailed information about the scheme and that they had difficulty, especially in the more complex cases, in being able to talk with people in Centrelink who had a solid understanding of the scheme's requirements. The complexity of the scheme was apparent from the large number of constituents I dealt with who had had to seek independent legal advice to decipher the laws and run their cases. Surely it was not the government's intention that applicants, most of whom had very limited financial means, would need to resort to solicitors to comprehend the scheme. This, if anything, suggests to me that amendments to the legislation and not just extension are necessary.

The Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme has undoubtedly helped the 1,400—or is it 1,550?—farmers who have been fortunate enough to meet the strict eligibility criteria. But one wonders how many worthy and justified applicants have missed out. I recall when the original RAFS legislation was introduced in 1998 that I received a letter from a Malcolm Martin of Coonabarabran who argued that only two per cent of retiring farmers were likely to qualify for the scheme. I said at the time I thought that claim was rather extreme. But, in considering this extension bill, this place deserves to know just how successful the scheme has been in meeting its objectives. As I did with the original bill, I offer my support for the bill. I would hope the government seriously reviews the value of this legislation in the interests of those farmers who deserve to access the pension but who have been unfairly missed out under this current regime for which $77 million was set aside but only $19 million will be spent even after this extension is taken into account.

talk.start.para: —I rise in support of the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme Extension Bill 2000, which extends an act that has already delivered enormous benefits to the local communities in rural and regional Australia. The Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme Extension Bill 2000 extends to 30 June 2001 the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme, which was expected to conclude on the 14th of next month. In 1996 this government constituted a special rural task force to investigate the impact of social security assets tests on farmers.

speech.para: The task force has also considered the effect of social security assets tests on the intergenerational transfer of the family farm. The task force report found that disposal provisions meant that farmers were frequently unable to transfer the farm as they could be precluded from the pension for five years. The report noted existing provisions hindered rather than encouraged the process. One farmer quoted by the task force observed:

quote.para: ... if I give the farm away my wife and I will have no money to live on for the next five years until we become eligible for the pension ... due to harsh conditions we haven't been able to return enough profit to support two families.

speech.para: How often have we who live in rural and regional Australia heard that said? The task force found that structures to support long-term planning either had not been available or had been too expensive for farmers to access. It recommended that, in order to ease the transfer of the farm, a temporary exemption from the disposal provisions should be provided where farms were to be transferred through to the children. As a response to the perceived needs of the rural sector, the government introduced its Agriculture Advancing Australia package. The AAA package provides both incentives for farm adjustment to ensure that there is an efficient and competitive farm sector and a welfare safety net for farmers.

The Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme is yet another initiative of this government when it came to power in 1996. This initiative is part of the Agriculture Advancing Australia package—better known as the AAA package—which was introduced by this government in 1997 to ensure a strong, ongoing future for this nation's farming sector. The aim of the AAA package is to help the rural sector to be more competitive, sustainable and profitable by focusing on four key objectives: to help farmers profit from change, to give farmers access to an effective welfare safety net, to provide incentives for ongoing farm adjustment, and to encourage social and economic development in rural areas.

I would like to remind the House and particularly those on the other side how successful the AAA package has been. More than 30,000 farmers have used the FarmBis program to improve their skills and training. Around 80 per cent of depositors have transferred their deposits from the former income equalisation deposit and farm management bond schemes to farm management deposits to take advantage of this attractive tax-effective risk management tool. The Farm Family Restart Scheme has helped more than 4,000 farmers in financial difficulty, while the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme has helped 1,484 retiring farmers in Australia. This includes 437 retiring farmers in New South Wales. In my electorate of New England, RAFS has helped 41 retiring farmers to pass on their farms to a younger generation and remain eligible for the age pension.

The cornerstones of the AAA package are the effective measures to address the key issues of rural adjustment, farm business risk management and skills development, drought, farm family welfare and rural community development. Unlike the opposition, those on this side of the House are deeply committed to the people of rural and regional Australia and do recognise that things have been tough in the bush for the best part of the last decade. Labor failed to provide programs to support farm families to manage change on the land. I would like to say that again: Labor failed to provide programs to support farm families to manage change on the land or, if necessary, to leave farming with dignity.

The Labor Party did not devote significant resources to education and training opportunities for farmers. With its Farm Household Support Scheme, Labor provided essentially a short-term loans scheme for farmers obliged to exit the industry. May I remind the House that this was subject to a means test, similar to what they suggest they might bring in for private health insurance—not very supportive, as it is now. This government abolished this ineffective scheme and forgave the outstanding debts in the scheme to the value of $5 million. The farm sector is critical to Australia's future prosperity. Improving the profitability, sustainability and competitiveness of our farmers will deliver benefits for everyone. In short, it will advance Australia. This government has laid a solid economic foundation through lower interest rates, a reduction in the value of the Australian dollar, and reforms in areas such as the labour market which had impacted on our national competitiveness and had been real barriers to the growth of our export industries and, of course, to our farmers.

The Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme provides an opportunity for eligible low income, pension-age farmers to gift their farms to a younger generation without affecting their age pension and to retire from farming. The Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme addition to existing provisions allows farmers to get immediate access to the age pension. The Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme is also open to eligible farmers who had transferred their farms to a younger generation after 15 September 1992. This helps many families living in hardship because their farms cannot support more than one family.

The main eligibility criteria for the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme are that the net value of the farm must be no more than $500,000; that retiring farmers must have owned the property for at least 15 years or have been actively involved in farming for 20 years; that retiring farmers must have had an average income less than the age pension rate in the preceding three years; and that the next generation must have had an active involvement in the farm for the three years prior to that transfer.

Where the farmer keeps the right to live on the farm after it has been transferred, the value of the home will not be included in the $500,000. Any equity in the farm enterprise held by the person to whom the farm is being transferred will also be excluded. Its extension for a further nine months will allow more farmers to reap the benefits of the scheme and they will be able to pass their farm on to their children, providing their family not only with a going concern but with a good sense of continuity and belonging to their community. At the same time, it will allow retiring farmers immediate access to the age pension or the service pension. The extension of this initiative, costing around $9 million over the next four years, will further contribute to a strong farming industry and will enable older farmers, including many veterans, to retire with peace of mind, leaving a proud legacy to the younger generation. This bill also makes amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. Amendments to this act extend the operation of the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme for the same time period to 30 June 2000.

In conclusion, this is the lucky country. For years Australia relied on the agricultural industry for the country's income, often being referred to as `riding on the sheep's back'. Now that the retiring farmers on whom society relied so heavily for the nation's income a few decades ago are in need of a little help, I am glad that this government has been able to provide that help for them. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —It is a pleasure to rise this evening to address the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme Extension Bill 2000. Really, those of us from rural electorates are keen to welcome this bill. I would like to cover some of the various elements in relation to it. The idea of this proposal stemmed from the Special Rural Task Force, which I suppose you could describe as the Tambling committee, because it was headed up by Senator Grant Tambling. It covered a range of issues looking at the way the social security network impacted on rural areas.

speech.para: Going to the explanation that that committee put together in its report on the impact of gifting provisions, I will quote what they had to say about gifting provisions—that is, those gifting provisions that applied at the time; and we are talking at the moment of those established in September 1996. The committee ran for a period of four months and, in its report, it said that the gifting provisions that applied at that time meant that:

quote.para: ... people may be excluded from a pension or allowance, or have their entitlements reduced for a period of five years, if they give away assets over $10,000 per year (the value of these assets are still counted in the person's total assets). In addition, deemed income is calculated on the amount gifted over $10,000 and this is counted as income under the person's income test during the five year period. The rationale is that those with substantial assets should use them to provide for their own support, rather than dispose of them. These rules apply to all Social Security payments but the issue is particularly relevant to older farmers seeking a pension.
These provisions mean that if a farmer wishes to retire and give (ie pass ownership of) the farm to the next generation, they could be precluded from a pension for five years.

speech.para: That was the situation as it applied as laid out by the Tambling committee, that Special Rural Task Force, in its report dated January 1997. But, of course, there were many problems with the regime and that difficulty laid out and identified by the committee. For example, it gave a couple of illustrations of cases that were submitted to the committee, and I will give one here. On page 34 of the committee's report, it quotes a farmer from New South Wales saying that:

quote.para: My problem is if I give the farm away my wife and I will have no money to live on for the next five years until we become eligible for the pension. While the property is a good one and we are both good managers, due to the economic conditions over the past seven years, and also a major bush fire six years ago, we haven't been able to return enough profit to reasonably support two families.

speech.para: That is one example, and there are also more on page 28 of that report. Another states:

quote.para: A widow of four years applied for widow's allowance because she has two sons home on the farm (one is married with three children). She was told that she was ineligible and that she should look for work. She wasn't successful and was then told she would have to sell the farm. With two sons who know no other lifestyle she felt she could not sell the farm. Yet there is insufficient income to keep three families.

speech.para: It continues:

quote.para: Now that stamp duty has been abolished, she will be able to transfer the farm over to her sons but will still have to wait five years for any assistance.

speech.para: Those examples make very clear the extent of the problem that was confronted by the Special Rural Task Force that in the end led to the establishment of the provisions that we are discussing tonight. That task force, in recommendation No. 15 of its report, stated:

motion.para: That to facilitate the inter-generational transfer of farm assets, a short term (eg two year) moratorium on the five year gifting provisions be applied for farmers planning retirement (from 63 years) or of pension age to give individual families a one off "window of opportunity" to plan and transfer the family farm. Qualification would be conditional upon:
. active involvement of the second generation in the farm operations for a minimum previous three years;
. an off farm assets test not exceeding the applicable assets test threshold;
. an income test consisting of average income over the previous three year period being less than the pension rate; and
. application to one farming enterprise.

speech.para: It then stated:

quote.para: Such a moratorium should be strongly promoted to the farming community.

speech.para: Such a proposal should be promoted very strongly in the farming community because it is exactly the kind of provision that the farming community was crying out for at that time. What ensued following the completion of the report of the Special Rural Task Force was consideration of that issue by the government and a decision by the government to include the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme proposal in the AAA package, the Agriculture Advancing Australia package.

Perhaps I can go into the elements of that because the AAA package was a very positive innovation and it provided a range of important measures that continue to assist agriculture in Australia. This particular part of it, the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme, was introduced in the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Retirement Assistance for Farmers) Act 1998. That was given royal assent on 2 July 1998.

When that scheme was introduced, these were the provisions that went along with it. As well as applying to people who fell within the period of the operation of the scheme—it was to start on 15 December 1997 and it was due for completion at the end of September 2000—it also applied to those who had transferred title to the new generation any time in the previous five years. That I think is a very welcome and generous provision that was provided by the government.

These are the circumstances that were applied to it, and I think members should reflect on the way this reflects the recommendations of the Special Rural Task Force. For example, it stated that the farm, except for the family home, must be transferred and that the value of the farm should be equal to or less than $500,000. It could not be transferred from a company but from a farmer or from a partnership involving the farmer and a spouse. Those people would have to have been in farming for 15 years. It was income and means tested and compared with the pension, as suggested by this special rural task force. Also, that comparison with the pension and that income would have been tested over a period of three years. The person who is the transferee under the requirements must have a farming background; also the transferee is required to be actively involved in farming for the three-year period prior to the transfer. Obviously, if you compare one with the other, the decision by the government very strongly reflects the position that the rural community was telling the government to adopt.

I have had the privilege, I suppose you might say, of listening to the member for Calare discuss this proposal tonight. I appreciate the comments he made because I am about to move into the area of discussing the criticisms that have been raised about this particular piece of legislation and the proposal that we confront now to extend it to June next year, which is a nine-month extension.

It is okay, I think, for people to bring attention to those criticisms, but the member for Calare is in the position of being an Independent who has chosen not to take part in policy development and not to submit himself to the discipline of being part of a party and having to develop a regime of policy making that fits the environment and is accountable. When you are in a position like that, you get the opportunity to adopt whatever level of criticism people want to throw at a scheme without necessarily having to follow up or be accountable yourself.

It was interesting to hear what the member for Calare had to say. I will discuss some of the criticism that has been raised in relation to this bill too, but I think members do have to give credit where it is due. In the words of the member for Calare, this program has undoubtedly assisted rural communities in Australia, so I think we should listen to that part of his speech much more closely than the other rabbiting on he did about some of the problems that apply.

Let us look at some of those problems. Farm groups said that the value of the property should be $800,000. To demonstrate the applicability of that figure, they used a 1997 farm survey report which said that the average value of farm businesses at that time was $968,000. That is probably a criticism you could take on board, but you have to remember that the purpose of this legislation is to address people who are really going to benefit from being able to move forward their entitlement to a pension. We are not talking about people who are at the upper end of the rural industry; we are talking about people who are operating a farm but wish to move on to a pension. I think the figure of $500,000 is appropriate in many cases in my electorate. I know that there would be people in higher levels than this, but I think one of the difficulties has been that people find themselves trapped, in effect, on a farm when it is no longer productive and when they really do need to move on to a pension. That is the problem that this legislation has been very effective in addressing, and I think credit deserves to be given in relation to that.

There was also criticism that there needed to be more flexibility to allow people to work off farm. I tend to support that, because the overwhelming trend at present with the falling commodity prices that we face and the difficulties that are emerging for people on the land—particularly when we are talking about a small holding with not much opportunity for people to make big profits—is that many of them are turning to off-farm income as a way of supplementing their existence. So this is really something that can be considered and perhaps addressed by the government in another way; certainly it could be addressed by way of more flexibility in this regard.

There was also criticism that there needs to be more time for succession planning in rural industries. I think we could apply this right across the board. I notice that the library's briefing on this issue that was given to members of parliament quoted a Western Australian survey which said that, when it comes to the problems of succession, only 14 per cent of farmers were succession planning. It said that, in 51 of 67 cases, difficulties in relation to succession planning had led to disagreements among those farming families. You could certainly argue that in no way can a piece of legislation, no matter how effective, serve to remove the personal element of transferring something as valuable and emotionally important as a family farm between generations. You will not get away from those kinds of difficulties and you will not get away from the problem of the older generation wanting to hang on, protect the asset and ensure that, for example, there is not going to be a marriage breakdown in the younger generation which may result in problems.

After two years of seeing the system in operation, I think we can say that it has been very successful. It was reviewed by the Department of Family and Community Services, and after year one it was found that 716 farmers and spouses had been assisted by the program. By June 2000, there had been 1,400 farmers and spouses assisted by it. However, I note that Senator Newman quoted a figure of 1,550 people who had been assisted by it as of 28 March 2000.

What is great about this bill we are looking at tonight is that we are going to be extending this program and opening it up for people to access right through until the end of this financial year. We have a nine-month extension. We have the opportunity for farmers to access that scheme right through until the year 2003-04, and the cost of that extension is quoted as being something like $7.5 million. It has been a very effective program and I really do think members from rural areas will welcome its longer introduction. It has been a complement to and a very important feature of the Agriculture Advancing Australia program.

In closing, I would like to reflect on some of the important developments that that package brought to Australian farms. For example, it included the creation of the tax linked Farm Management Deposit Scheme. It included $50 million for the extension of business management skills under the Farm Business Improvement Program, known as FarmBis. It allowed older farmers to transfer the ownership of the family farm to the younger generation—the very issue which we have addressed tonight. That was cited at the time as having a value of $77 million. It also continued the exceptional circumstances assistance to farmers through two different provisions. It also provided the Farm Family Restart Scheme, introduced from 1 December 1997, which was worth $120 million. And it included the improved Rural Communities Program, worth a total of $40 million, to provide assistance to rural communities.

The Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme is worth while. It has now been in place since royal assent was granted on 2 July 1998. I would like to say on behalf of primary producers in my area that it has resulted in many positive applications and many people have been able to overcome problems that many of them, I honestly believe, had thought were insurmountable. In closing, I would like to welcome its extension and urge members to continue to look for other ways in which we can assist the intergenerational transfer of farms because of course this is the way in which we drive up the productivity of these farms. We have a problem where the farming community is an ageing community. In some of the material that I have here, it is stated that the average age of farmers is 55. I would swear that that age is going up. I am sure members are keen to see more keen young farmers brought into the system, so that we can look to the future and find new ways to boost productivity, new methods and new profitability not only for the farmers themselves but for the communities out there that are desperately reliant on a profitable rural sector.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr BRUCE SCOTT
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —In summing up, I would firstly like to thank all members who have contributed to the debate on the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme Extension Bill 2000. I note that some concerns have been raised by the opposition—in fact, they have put forward an amendment—and the member for Calare had some concerns on which I would like to comment during my summing up.

speech.para: This bill extends the successful Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme for a further nine months, as members on this side of the House have pointed out, until 30 June 2001. The Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme is a key initiative of the Agriculture Advancing Australia, or what became commonly known as the AAA package, which was an initiative of this federal government, introduced by the then minister for agriculture and now Deputy Prime Minister. The AAA package has delivered unprecedented support to the rural sector and is ensuring a strong ongoing future for our nation's farming sector, focusing very heavily on the competitiveness, the sustainability, the productivity and, importantly also, the profitability of our farming sector. The Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme provides older farmers with an opportunity to transfer their farms to the younger generation without affecting their access to service pensions, for those who are eligible for them through the Department of Veterans' Affairs, and also to age pensions for those who are eligible to access them.

At the time the scheme was introduced, the departmental submission to the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee, which examined the original bill, estimated that 2,100 farmers would be able to apply and qualify for the pension under the Rural Assistance for Farmers Scheme. I note that the opposition's amendment suggests that, whilst they do not want to decline to give the bill a second reading, they are talking about a figure of something like 10,000 farmers to retire with dignity and control of their farm assets passing into the next generation. In other words, they are saying that the government is failing to meet its target. I refer the opposition to the departmental submission given to that Senate committee. The submission's original target was 2,100 farmers. I am not quite sure where the opposition got their figure of 10,000 from. It seems to be something that was plucked out of the air, or perhaps it might have come out of the Hobart conference. But if the opposition care to look at the department's submission given at that Senate committee, they will see quite clearly that the original target—the estimated number of farmers that would benefit from the scheme—was 2,100. As of 30 June 2000, some 1,724 farmers have accessed the scheme. With the extension of the scheme for a further nine months, this will enable additional farmers to qualify for the assistance.

The member for Calare suggested in his comments on this bill that there were originally an estimated 1,550 farmers who may benefit from the scheme. He is suggesting now that only 1,400 have been able to benefit. He commented that the numbers that were suggested earlier this year have declined. I can only suggest to the member for Calare that perhaps he has looked at the numbers of those who have accessed the scheme who have been able to access an age pension through Centrelink—in other words, the Centrelink numbers, which are 1,400. The numbers that perhaps he has not looked at are those who have been able to access a Department of Veterans' Affairs entitlement—in other words, a service pension—through my own Department of Veterans' Affairs, which are 324 farmers. So I refer the member to those figures because as at 30 June some 1,724 farmers have accessed the scheme—and that figure is made up of those two components. I also noted the comments of the member for Calare in relation to a report that he has been trying to gain access to. I will certainly make sure that the Minister for Family and Community Services is aware of his comments in relation to that report.

The Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme has successfully aided farmers who have been experiencing hardship—I know in my own electorate there are many in this category—and who also wish to retire. This scheme has enabled them to pass on the farm to the next generation so that we can get intergenerational transfer of the farm asset. That means that there will be a continuation of the tradition of the family farm. It has also eased the financial burden of trying to find sufficient income from one farm to support two or more families. That is an extremely important point and why this scheme has been very successful. The bill does not alter any of the other eligibility requirements of the scheme. Farmers will need to meet the eligibility criteria of the scheme as it has been operating for the last three years. So the criteria are not changing; we are extending the bill for a further nine months to 30 June 2001. With more than 1,724 farmers and their partners who have accessed and benefited from this scheme, I believe that this nine-month extension will enable even more farmers to retire and have immediate access to an age or a service pension. I commend the bill to the House.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
